(4:57:43 PM) efried: mriedem: I say no bp, bug good, reno optional'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-03-21 23:02:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

I'm too tired to review the tests, so won't vote, but a comment within.

Also, with regard to a reno: My initial thought was no, if this works as it should nobody will notice except maybe they'll boot quicker. It's not a mechanism that people need to know about. But then I remembered the extent to which field people insist on knowing exactly where and how in the scheduling process things have gone wrong and get disappointed when there's another step in that process and they didn't know about it.

So if there isn't a reno, maybe there should be a plan to make a "here are all the pre-filters and how to debug them" doc, since it's, like, a trend now.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-03-22 02:53:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

> So if there isn't a reno, maybe there should be a plan to make a "here are all the pre-filters and how to debug them" doc, since it's, like, a trend now.

Yup, I thought about that after the fact, but it could be called out either in:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/configuration/schedulers.html

somewhere, or:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/manage-volumes.html#volume-multi-attach

The latter is a more natural fit IMO given the context.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-03-22 02:55:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

Missed some obscure cells v1 unit test. Need to update docs, not persist the change and add a bug.'}, {'account_id': 15888, 'date': '2019-03-22 07:14:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-03-22 08:05:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-03-22 14:29:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-03-22 14:36:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

I'll  test some of this stuff"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-03-22 16:13:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

My earlier comment made zero sense. However, I did produce a simple gabbi based demonstration of traits and children: https://github.com/cdent/placecat/blob/master/gabbits/trait-pairs.yaml

It mostly seems about what you would expect: an un-numbered required is a sort of global filter: it applies to unspecified child providers.

However if you request a class specifically with a numbered 'resources1' then it's traits need to be specified directly too. A global required isn't a part of that: https://github.com/cdent/placecat/blob/aa24a7cd7d89584d7136a0fbdfbfa4a4e76480f4/gabbits/trait-pairs.yaml#L90

I'm uncertain if all that represents the desired functionality or not, but figured I'd lay it out there for a looksee"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-03-22 16:27:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> I did produce a simple gabbi based demonstration of traits and children

Thanks for doing that, Chris. For the case we care about here, with the setup you have, I think it would look like:

 - name: get via unnumbered required but numbered resources
   GET: /allocation_candidates?resources1=VCPU:1&resources2=DISK_GB:1;required=STORAGE_DISK_SSD
   status: ???
   response_json_paths:
       $.errors[0].detail: /orphaned traits/ ???
   response_json_paths:
       $.allocation_requests.`len`: ???

More precisely, if it matters (it might not), this case wants the trait on the root. A corner case also wants no resources requested from wherever the trait lives.

If you don't want to keep chasing this, let me know and I'll play around with it."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-03-22 17:47:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> If you don't want to keep chasing this, let me know and I'll play
 > around with it.

I'll add that case, so we have it.

This stuff is contributing to my growing lack of enthusiasm for nested. I think we need to keep very clear in our minds that use of nested is a very specialist situation, a corner case, a thing that normal humans should never ever have to concern themselves with. Yet such a huge vast amount of time has been devoted to it and its related use cases. That's not a good thing.

Which is not to say "let's forget about it", just that we should expect more from those specialist users when it comes to creating this stuff.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-03-22 17:59:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

https://github.com/cdent/placecat/blob/d3241a6fb0d8701072986c169615787f7484a3b7/gabbits/trait-pairs.yaml#L109

Is a 400, which is what I would expect given the way we parse query strings. If we wanted to parse them different we probably could. Hard to say how the database query side of things would like that.

In terms of the general case of "how does required work (assuming knowns about query string processing" I think the other case at https://github.com/cdent/placecat/blob/d3241a6fb0d8701072986c169615787f7484a3b7/gabbits/trait-pairs.yaml#L89 is potentially more of a concern. Is it what we expect?'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-03-22 22:08:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> I think we need to keep very clear in our minds that use of nested is a very specialist situation, a corner case,

I don't agree with this at all. At its most basic, nested gives us a way to model resources of the same class but different traits. That is far from a corner case in real life.

Unless you're suggesting we should just do that with separate providers which are associated with each other through some mechanism other than nesting. What is that mechanism? Not aggregates, unless we make them a lot more powerful. Do away with the concept of "parent" and just have root_provider_id, so they're still tied together but not in a tree structure? That could help here, but it won't fly for e.g. NUMA. We could invent a whole new thing to make it easier to associate providers with each other, but that would be... inventing a whole new thing.

> a thing that normal humans should never ever have to concern themselves with.

What do we mean by "normal humans"? Is that a cloud user? Totally agree: they want to be able to select a flavor called "wicked fast image recognition". The operator human has to do a little more work to set that up, because it means the CPU, memory, and GPU have to come from the same NUMA node. That's not a corner case for operators; it's why we have NUMA syntax in flavor extra specs. So developer humans need to figure out a way to make that happen.

> we should expect more from those specialist users when it comes to creating this stuff.

Expect more what? Development resources? Descriptions of use cases? Right now we're not hearing clamoring for e.g. NUMA-via-placement support because NUMA is already supported. What operator/customer/user is going to bang down our door asking us to do a bunch of work to make this thing that already works still work with different plumbing?

No - we're doing this to make it work better, faster, cleaner. To get rid of hackish code we hate in favor of hopefully-less hackish code we don't. To get all resources represented in the same way so the code is easier to understand and maintain. Basically, we're doing it for ourselves. Is that wrong? I can't imagine considering the current state - where some resources are tracked in placement, some in nova databases, some in both - acceptable as any form of "done" to where we could stop trying to push toward all resources tracked in placement. To get that done we're going to have to handle hard scenarios like this.

I'm not trying to be difficult with all of the above; where there are questions marks I'm genuinely asking questions.

> https://github.com/cdent/placecat/blob/d3241a6fb0d8701072986c169615787f7484a3b7/gabbits/trait-pairs.yaml#L109
> 
> Is a 400, which is what I would expect given the way we parse query strings. If we wanted to parse them different we probably could. Hard to say how the database query side of things would like that.

Yeah, this is the one I was concerned about. I want to see what happens when we take that early check out and let this go to the lower-level methods. If it "just works" we might want to consider doing that, in some careful way, in a new microversion, because it would be a simple way to solve the problem at hand.

> In terms of the general case of "how does required work (assuming knowns about query string processing" I think the other case at https://github.com/cdent/placecat/blob/d3241a6fb0d8701072986c169615787f7484a3b7/gabbits/trait-pairs.yaml#L89 is potentially more of a concern. Is it what we expect?

It's a little weird because we don't require group_policy when just one numbered group is given. And ugh, I don't remember how group_policy=isolate interacts with the unnumbered group. But I'm not surprised that this is operating as it is, because we're processing the groups individually, and the group that's asking for that trait is also not asking for resource provided by the provider with that trait.

...and that line of thought makes me believe that the "see what happens" above will almost certainly not "just work".

====

A way to do this without placement API changes would be to add the compute capability traits to not just the root provider. At the moment I don't know if that means adding them to all providers in the tree (which would be fairly easy, but I'm not sure it makes sense); or adding them to all providers of VCPU resources (ditto).'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-03-22 23:48:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> > I think we need to keep very clear in our minds that use of
 > nested is a very specialist situation, a corner case,
 > 
 > I don't agree with this at all. At its most basic, nested gives us
 > a way to model resources of the same class but different traits.
 > That is far from a corner case in real life.

Caring about traits is not the common case. The common case is "give me a vm with enough cpu and memory and disk." Some traits are likely going to be common (like STORAGE_DISK_SSD). Many others, most others, will not.

 > Unless you're suggesting we should just do that with separate
 > providers which are associated with each other through some
 > mechanism other than nesting.

As I tried to say before, I'm not saying we shouldn't do it. Nor am I saying it is not important. I'm saying it is outside the 80/20 case and we should take that into account when managing our own precious resources.

 > > a thing that normal humans should never ever have to concern
 > themselves with.
 > 
 > What do we mean by "normal humans"? Is that a cloud user? Totally
 > agree: they want to be able to select a flavor called "wicked fast
 > image recognition".

I doubt they want that that frequently. They want what I described above. Do some people want wicked fast image recognition? Sure they do. Can we accomplish that by having nested that the operator manipulates, sure. Are we doing that. Yes.

But having it be the sine qua non of our existence (yes, yes, I know, I exaggerate, I'm an artist) is destructive to the overall product. I'm not saying we shouldn't do it or pay attention to it. I'm merely expressing frustration that for the past two years so much of many of our brains has been devoted to this thing that while we are finally seeing some real progress on,  continues to feel like a large source of complexity that draws us into much wheel spinning.

Consider this patch we're on right now. What we care about is that we're able to do a trait-based pre filter. In the common current case where we ask for the VPCU on the root provider (because that's the only place we put it, now) it will just work and will provide the "better faster cleaner you describe.

But it opens a can of worms as we start thinking about a predicted future where there may be no resources on the root. We don't know when that future will be, or even for certain if it will ever be, but we've spun up plenty of brain power to try to plan for that eventuality and explore the many variables, an exploration which because we are in the context of nested often suffers from exponential growth.

I don't think we are in a position where we (and by we I mean the people who regularly work on nova and placement) can afford to expend that energy as blithely as we have in the past. We need to focus on the stuff that we know for sure, now. We have mechanisms in place with microversions, database migrations, and simple dumb human communication to be able to compensate for efforts we do now that turn out to be misfires or outright errors later.

In this particular case, the use case can be satisfied. Which is awesome. All of us together have done good things to make that possible.

It's probably going to break if we ever get to the no inventory on the root situation. Okay, let's deal with that when we get there, our plates are already more than full.

 > > we should expect more from those specialist users when it comes
 > to creating this stuff.
 > 
 > Expect more what? Development resources? Descriptions of use cases?

Development resources and capacity to engage in the process of "fixing it when we get there". We operate like an abused child who is so scared of mummy and daddy they make sure their room is perfectly clean when in fact mummy and daddy are barely paying attention to the details of the room or anything else and in the meantime we haven't done our homework, and managed to fail high school. Deliver the half-baked to those specialist users and we have an opportunity to make contributors out of them. Give them perfection and they've got nothing to do.

Which is not to say we are striving for perfection. We are a long way from that. But we're not iterating effectively. We haven't figured out a good way to enable feedback on things that are not ready, to let users/operators experiment and respond. And I think part of (but certainly not all) the reason for that is because we spend too much effort trying to predict.

 > "done" to where we could stop trying to push toward all resources
 > tracked in placement. To get that done we're going to have to
 > handle hard scenarios like this.

Yes, and we should continue to do so, but it should be less...primary. We need to deliver more value, more often, to more people.

 > I'm not trying to be difficult with all of the above; where there
 > are questions marks I'm genuinely asking questions.

I appreciate and understand and I hope you understand that the reason I'm ranting is because I think we can improve the process that we are all working in to get to more better/faster/cleaner and I don't think we talk about that sort of thing realistically often enough. I'm sure others reading this are like "wtf has this got to do with pre-filtering hosts"?

 > Yeah, this is the one I was concerned about. I want to see what
 > happens when we take that early check out and let this go to the
 > lower-level methods. If it "just works" we might want to consider
 > doing that, in some careful way, in a new microversion, because it
 > would be a simple way to solve the problem at hand.

Can we wait? As a _project_ can we be more a queue than a stack, whatever work styles individual's might prefer? Among many other benefits, it makes progress and opportunities to apply effort more apparent to secondary and tertiary participants.

Can we put taking "that early check out" to the end of the queue? If we need to address it before we reach it naturally we know where to look. If you start looking into it now, then there is a bit of an implicit obligation for not only for me to start thinking about it a little bit, but for Ed, Jay, Gibi, Tetsuro and other people too, and we all have a great deal of other stuff we were already doing.

Such is the nature of the way we do open and highly reviewed work.

There's a vast sidebar here on the nature of leadership in open communities and setting examples and all that, but going down that road right now, at quarter to midnight would be setting a horrible example. Which I'll take as my queue to wind down.

 > A way to do this without placement API changes would be to add the
 > compute capability traits to not just the root provider. At the
 > moment I don't know if that means adding them to all providers in
 > the tree (which would be fairly easy, but I'm not sure it makes
 > sense); or adding them to all providers of VCPU resources (ditto).

Lest I be misconstrued I'm not making my arguments because I want to avoid making changes in placement. If we need changes, when we need changes, let's make them.

Adding compute host capability traits to anything but the root, assuming the root is the compute host (the place we call spawn), having capabilities somewhere else is icky. While that manages to work, we're groovy.

Sorry, Matt, for hijacking you review. It's a good change, glad to see it. Glad we have the bits that enable this relatively simple improvement. Needs some minor tweaks then groovy.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-03-25 12:10:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I started working on adding the request groups from the flavor to the requested_resources https://review.openstack.org/#/c/647396

This will make possible to add a multiattach trait to the unnumbered group to drive the scheduling'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2019-03-25 12:57:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I don't want to weigh in on each and every point of this discussion, but while reading through it I was brought back to the discussions we had on nested in Dublin that were so infuriatingly complex that I started my investigations into graph databases as a better model for placement.

Nested providers are an edge case, that's true. But given the amount of effort we've been putting into talking about it, it's certainly not something insignificant. I will take this discussion as an opportunity to restate my strong belief that the source of the friction with nested providers is that while it is possible to model them in SQL, it is a terrible match. I do understand that it is a little too idealistic to imagine that we would ever reconsider our choice of SQL, but it does seem that we continuously underestimate the degree of complexity and instability that we are introducing into placement with nested. Both the complexity as well as our continuous denial of the true extent of that instability are both horrible "code smells" (really, design smells) that is what I think Chris is reacting to.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-03-26 08:09:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-03-26 08:26:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-04-22 22:08:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2019-05-03 22:35:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

So I think we all know that multiattach is not the only use case for this. Device tags come to mind [1]. So I think we need a more wholesale approach to convert the instance boot request into a bunch of compute capability traits, with some of them being persisted and some not. Because multiattach and device tags can change, those should probably not be persisted, but then for every operation that goes through the scheduler we'll need to check whether the instance still has multi-attached volumes and/or devices with tags, and construct a thing (RequestSpec?) accordingly.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1817927"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-05-06 16:53:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> but then for every operation that goes through the scheduler we'll need to check whether the instance still has multi-attached volumes and/or devices with tags, and construct a thing (RequestSpec?) accordingly.

Correct, see the comment inline about move operations. Since the attached bdms can change, they are not persisted on the request spec. We could do a request filter in the scheduler to pull bdms, but since the multiattach information is stored in the bdm.connection_info, that wouldn't work during server create (since we don't update connection_info until we update the attachment record in the compute service). We could determine if there are tags though. We could also add a multiattach attribute to the bdm object itself (like the tag), and then we'd need some kind of data migration to set it if it's an existing bdm and the connection_info has to be read to get the multiattach value of the connection (or read the volume from cinder)."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-05-06 16:54:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Note there is a TODO to add a multiattach attribute to the BDM:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/5934c5dc6932fbf19ca7f3011c4ccc07b0038ac4/nova/virt/block_device.py#L549'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-08-20 21:34:06.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

I'm not actively pursuing this, it was mostly an exercise at the time. We can restore this if someone has an interest in making this work."}]

commit_message:
Pre-filter hosts based on multiattach volume support

With change I15364d37fb7426f4eec00ca4eaf99bec50e964b6 in
Stein the COMPUTE_VOLUME_MULTI_ATTACH trait will be automatically
added to compute node resource providers for compute drivers that
have the supports_multiattach=True capability. We can leverage that
in the API to modify the RequestSpec if we are creating a server
with pre-existing multiattach volumes to require the trait during
scheduling, which is what this change does.

This is useful for deployments with mixed hypervisors where
one driver supports multiattach volumes but another does not.

Change-Id: Ic6018078ac238232033098d2920a3c1fa890f113

commit_message:
Do not create default security group during instance create if using Neutron

The DB API was unconditionally creating a 'default' security group
per project when an instance is created, but if you're using neutron
the security_groups table entries are not used anyway, so this simply
avoids that security group code when using neutron.

Change-Id: I723a90d4122e3df531cc3624c5fa1fd2ea4a8a46
Related-Bug: #1824435

commit_message:
Modify volume multiattach boot from volume test to use two servers

The boot from multiattach volume test is much more interesting when
we're creating two servers against the same multiattach volume, since
that should be possible now.

Change-Id: I702a9afba727ef1b6445f55b5442d9a227948a0c
Related-Bug: #1747985

commit_message:
Remove osops-tools-monitoring-oschecks for RHEL 8

The osops-tools-monitoring-oschecks package is not supported in
RHEL 8.

Change-Id: Ib667087532317548042b406d61517b62659bcf3c
(cherry picked from commit 2d2bc4d8b20304d0939ac0cebedac7bda3398def)

commit_message:
Add functional recreate test for bug 1823370

When evacuating a server in a multi-cell environment
we should be restricting the scheduling request during
evacuate to the cell in which the instance already exists
since we don't support cross-cell evacuate.

This adds a functional test to recreate the bug to show
that the scheduler is not restricted to the instance's
current cell when evacuating.

Change-Id: I56e20c84f25cc4961dc8d637c222b6f213c4d5f9
Related-Bug: #1823370

commit_message:
Use config_drive for network basicops tests

For running network basicops tests, we need to set
compute_feature_enabled.config_drive to true so that
user-data should be passed to the cirros vm while booting.

Related-Bug: #1836046

Change-Id: Ieac018bf19481666e0db31dfa70a78dd0dc3f046
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

commit_message:
[FUP] Backport - krb-service-principal metadata per-Role

The rocky and queens backport of change[1] missed updating a
deprecated environment file that is no longer present since
stein.

This change updates the deprecated environment file to be a
j2 file with the jinja code to render the per-role metadata.

[1] I5ae3bc845b0a6ad6986d44b14ff4b0737a9b033b

Related-Bug: #1821377
Change-Id: Ie7c3c448e8d0f53a5347a19b6d0b99a0c6097114
(cherry picked from commit fb5f69dcb2f84797d75da8b2a75692e06ed873f0)

commit_message:
Migrate install to deploy-guide

The deployment guide is currently pointed at triplo-docs but it has been
requested that we actually publish a deployment guide. This change
extracts many of the installation doc pages and moves them into the
deploy-guide source tree.  Once the deploy-guide is published, we will
follow up to reference the deployment guide from tripleo-docs.

Change-Id: I0ebd26f014180a92c6cf4ab0929d99b2d860796f

commit_message:
[ceph-osd] fix name of ceph-osd daemonset during upgrades

This is to resolve ds name changes  during the site update which triggers
all osds to start at a time and deletes old ds which is causing some timesouts
on clients.

Change-Id: If004e8e46ea34d90d7e05dc41e873c7a64ec046f

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-30 14:21:16.000000000', 'message': "Modify paths to ensure that charms' charmhelpers is first

The pre-patch version of unit-testing tested the git-repo version of
charm-helpers instead of the version that was synced to the charm.

The git-repo version of charmhelpers is pip installed to obtain the
testing part of charm-helpers, for the unit tests.  Whilst this is a bug
(really), it was compounded in that - due to how the paths worked - the
unit tests' git version of charm-helpers was in the path first, and thus
all unit tests were performed using that version of charm-helpers, and
not the version actually synced into the charm.  This has led to all
sorts of 'odd' double mocking of config in the tests as there are
potentially two copies of charm-helpers (as was the case for py27).  A
further commit will undo that madness.

This patchset moves the charm synced version of charm-helpers earlier
into the path so it gets picked first when the modules are loaded.

Change-Id: Iff0566c52a283ff0cd2fc7707d981d8c47f3e6b2
"}]
commit_message:
Modify paths to ensure that charms' charmhelpers is first

The pre-patch version of unit-testing tested the git-repo version of
charm-helpers instead of the version that was synced to the charm.

The git-repo version of charmhelpers is pip installed to obtain the
testing part of charm-helpers, for the unit tests.  Whilst this is a bug
(really), it was compounded in that - due to how the paths worked - the
unit tests' git version of charm-helpers was in the path first, and thus
all unit tests were performed using that version of charm-helpers, and
not the version actually synced into the charm.  This has led to all
sorts of 'odd' double mocking of config in the tests as there are
potentially two copies of charm-helpers (as was the case for py27).  A
further commit will undo that madness.

This patchset moves the charm synced version of charm-helpers earlier
into the path so it gets picked first when the modules are loaded.

Change-Id: Iff0566c52a283ff0cd2fc7707d981d8c47f3e6b2

[{'account_id': 24904, 'date': '2018-01-02 23:23:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-01-02 23:23:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

commit_message:
Allow charm to call init with it's own arguments

Implements addational ceph broker calls for setting more options on the
ceph-fs pool.
* pool_type
* compression
* weight
* erasure options

Change-Id: If19f3dd454d8726b8b8d8ca4b105532219f0f3f0
Partial-Bug: #1740726
Depends-On: I35ef8682e08464d0e8f4d1d899cbdd6a2629a214

remove the screen package as its no longer supported.

commit_message:
Add support for RHEL 8 and start using versionless element

A new versionless rhel element has been added in DIB. Start using
that, and add the RHEL 8 bindings as well.

Change-Id: I65d65f954e2d18d4493486c27f5b049dc7910846

commit_message:
Fix log update-status error

This patch adds a dummy update_status function so that the update-status
hook 'has' a function to run and thus silence the log error.

Change-Id: Ia0ed9367809fd47c10ad6a57011555589a7d940c
Closes-bug: #1837639

commit_message:
Remove deprecated common.http.HTTPClient class

The class common.http.HTTPClient is deprecated and merked for
removal in Stein.
This patch removes it entirely, the class common.http.SessionClient
should be used instead.

Change-Id: I527d39d64c3ded9f61babcdf07d0492799b76fb9
Story: 2006422
Task: 36314

commit_message:
Upgrade pylint to a version that works with python3

Fixes a few pylint warning from this recent pylint.

len-as-condition, inconsistent-return-statements and
no-else-return rules are
added to the ignore list in .pylintrc because they are
patterns commonly used in the neutron stadium and
already ignored in the neutron repo.

astroid version needs to be specified too.
Otherwise, a newer version of astroid which conflicts with pylint 2.2.0
will be installed. astroid and pylint are tightly coupled,
so both versions should be specified.

urllib2 is only available for python2.
In python3, it has been merged into urllib.
six.moves.urllib needs to be used.

Change-Id: Ib8f25b8103f6bb429cf5fbaa7a071dab7326930f
Co-Author: Akihiro Motoki <amotoki@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-20 07:07:46.000000000', 'message': 'simple-init: add configurable RA timeout with network-manager

This is a follow-on to I475a253091cbaf63687b91c748c31a6753bb0f57 as we
are still seeing issues on some clouds with unconfigured networking.

We increase the timeout, but also make it configurable so we can
fiddle it without a dib release in the gate.

To follow-on from the experimentation done by clarkb, I can confirm by
emperical testing on a Centos 7 image (from today, today being this
change's date) that setting

 net.ipv6.conf.all.autoconf=0

by itself is "fatal" and the interfaces do not come up; i.e. nm does
not by default seem to re-enable ipv6 for the interface.  However,
explicitly adding:

 IPV6INIT=yes
 IPV6_AUTOCONF=yes

to the interface file *does* seem to make it work, even if
"all.autoconf=0" is set (then again, there's also bugs about the
effect of this [1]).  However, no extant distribution (I can currently
find) does anything like this by default.

If this continues, this may be an option.  Another might be to avoid
the use of the nm-settings-ifcfg-rh profiles and move directly to nm
ini files with glean.

[1] https://bugzilla.kernel.org/show_bug.cgi?id=11655

Change-Id: I869ebffc8cde3bbff573f6583fd9dd02a5598590
'}]
commit_message:
simple-init: add configurable RA timeout with network-manager

This is a follow-on to I475a253091cbaf63687b91c748c31a6753bb0f57 as we
are still seeing issues on some clouds with unconfigured networking.

We increase the timeout, but also make it configurable so we can
fiddle it without a dib release in the gate.

To follow-on from the experimentation done by clarkb, I can confirm by
emperical testing on a Centos 7 image (from today, today being this
change's date) that setting

 net.ipv6.conf.all.autoconf=0

by itself is "fatal" and the interfaces do not come up; i.e. nm does
not by default seem to re-enable ipv6 for the interface.  However,
explicitly adding:

 IPV6INIT=yes
 IPV6_AUTOCONF=yes

to the interface file *does* seem to make it work, even if
"all.autoconf=0" is set (then again, there's also bugs about the
effect of this [1]).  However, no extant distribution (I can currently
find) does anything like this by default.

If this continues, this may be an option.  Another might be to avoid
the use of the nm-settings-ifcfg-rh profiles and move directly to nm
ini files with glean.

[1] https://bugzilla.kernel.org/show_bug.cgi?id=11655

Change-Id: I869ebffc8cde3bbff573f6583fd9dd02a5598590

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-13 20:35:14.000000000', 'message': 'Microversion 2.75 - Multiple API cleanup changes

Add support microversion 2.75 which implement
multiple API cleanup changes.

1. 400 for unknown param for query param and for request body.
 - This does not need any changes in client side as you cannot
pass the unknown parameters in APIs.

2. Making server representation always consistent among all APIs
   returning the complete server representation.
 - Test cases added.

3. Change the default return value of ``swap`` field from the empty string
   to 0 (integer) in flavor APIs.
 - Test cases added.

4. Return ``servers`` field always in the response of GET
   hypervisors API even there are no servers on hypervisor
 - No changes needed as empty table is shown when no servers.

Nova side path: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/666889/

Change-Id: Iec2cfc629dffd53178ef88a31fcd16a3f32e2e27
Partial-Implements: blueprint api-consistency-cleanup

commit_message:
Microversion 2.75 - Multiple API cleanup changes

Add support microversion 2.75 which implement
multiple API cleanup changes.

1. Making server representation always consistent among all APIs
   returning the complete server representation.
 - Test cases added.

2. Change the default return value of ``swap`` field from the empty string
   to 0 (integer) in flavor APIs.
 - Test cases added.

Nova side path: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/666889/

Change-Id: Iec2cfc629dffd53178ef88a31fcd16a3f32e2e27
Partial-Implements: blueprint api-consistency-cleanup

commit_message:
Add more promote docs jobs

Add promote-openstack-tox-docs-direct job for publishing jobs without
/latest.

Add promote-tox-docs-infra job for publishing infra repos.
Convert osf/openstackid to use it and remove release job, the infra job
does not handle releases extra.

commit_message:
Point InternalTLSVncCAFile to /etc/ipa/ca.crt

In case the freeipa CA is a sub CA of an external CA the
InternalTLSVncCAFile requrested does not have the full CA
chain and only have the free IPA CA. As a result qemu
which can not verify the vnc certificate sent by the
vnc-proxy. The issue is in certmonger[1] as it does not return the
full CA chain.


As a workaround, until certmonger is fixed, this change points the
InternalTLSVncCAFile to /etc/ipa/ca.crt which has the full CA chain.

[1] - https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1710632

Change-Id: Id2392dd076e216b4cd5b405d893ec2959456673e
(cherry picked from commit b93c672313ae2925de7e7c844e19b6a0484b5eae)

[{'account_id': 14482, 'date': '2019-08-01 14:28:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-08-01 15:08:03.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from i18n-atc to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-08-01 15:08:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-08-01 15:14:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(6 comments)

@Ian - Several people on the ATC list are not showing up in the Foundation community member database on openstack.org. I believe that means that even as ATCs, they will not be able to vote. They may also lose other privileges, but I'm not sure. I have linked to the log output for each person who isn't in the database so you don't have to scan the logs yourself."}, {'account_id': 14482, 'date': '2019-08-01 15:25:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14482, 'date': '2019-08-01 15:29:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Doug: Thanks a lot for pointing out this and I appreciate TC's implementation on such an additional validation! Actually I relied on an Ansible implementation managed in I18n repo [1] but seems that the implementation needs to be revised to see json output from Foundation member check calls.

 > @Ian - Several people on the ATC list are not showing up in the
 > Foundation community member database on openstack.org. I believe

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/i18n/src/branch/master/playbooks/generate_atc.yml#L77"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-08-05 12:34:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-08-05 12:36:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> @Doug: Thanks a lot for pointing out this and I appreciate TC's
 > implementation on such an additional validation! Actually I relied
 > on an Ansible implementation managed in I18n repo [1] but seems
 > that the implementation needs to be revised to see json output from
 > Foundation member check calls.
 > 
 > > @Ian - Several people on the ATC list are not showing up in the
 > > Foundation community member database on openstack.org. I believe
 > 
 > [1] https://opendev.org/openstack/i18n/src/branch/master/playbooks/generate_atc.yml#L77

I wasn't able to make the URL linked there give me useful query results, but I didn't spend much time on it. You might want to confirm with the Foundation that that API works the way it's being used. Alternatively, you could use the openstack_governance library as an API to do the validation. If we don't have a command line tool for it already, it should be straightforward to add one to make the ansible integration easier."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-08-05 18:14:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> I believe that means that even as ATCs, they will not be able to vote.

By definition an ATC must be a member of the Foundation; I don't believe we can approve ATCs who are not. See appendix 4, section 3(a)(ii) of the bylaws: https://www.openstack.org/legal/technical-committee-member-policy/"}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-08-12 13:05:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-08-12 13:06:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Rollcall-Vote'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-08-12 14:05:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-08-12 14:09:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-08-12 16:13:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-08-12 16:50:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1

I think we're good in this case because the CI test passed fine so at this point all the ATCs are valid foundation members."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-08-13 15:47:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-08-15 16:00:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-08-16 03:01:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2019-08-16 05:10:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-08-16 14:34:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-08-20 18:45:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Point InternalTLSVncCAFile to /etc/ipa/ca.crt

In case the freeipa CA is a sub CA of an external CA the
InternalTLSVncCAFile requrested does not have the full CA
chain and only have the free IPA CA. As a result qemu
which can not verify the vnc certificate sent by the
vnc-proxy. The issue is in certmonger[1] as it does not return the
full CA chain.

As a workaround, until certmonger is fixed, this change points the
InternalTLSVncCAFile to /etc/ipa/ca.crt which has the full CA chain.

[1] - https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1710632

Change-Id: Id2392dd076e216b4cd5b405d893ec2959456673e
(cherry picked from commit ade09f3a3405f47fa9524ef4baea155a4262175b)

commit_message:
Point InternalTLSVncCAFile to /etc/ipa/ca.crt

In case the freeipa CA is a sub CA of an external CA the
InternalTLSVncCAFile requrested does not have the full CA
chain and only have the free IPA CA. As a result qemu
which can not verify the vnc certificate sent by the
vnc-proxy. The issue is in certmonger[1] as it does not return the
full CA chain.

As a workaround, until certmonger is fixed, this change points the
InternalTLSVncCAFile to /etc/ipa/ca.crt which has the full CA chain.

[1] - https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1710632

Change-Id: I750c5572505ff58b8164906754f1bcaf4fd256e0

commit_message:
Point InternalTLSVncCAFile to /etc/ipa/ca.crt

In case the freeipa CA is a sub CA of an external CA the
InternalTLSVncCAFile requrested does not have the full CA
chain and only have the free IPA CA. As a result qemu
which can not verify the vnc certificate sent by the
vnc-proxy. The issue is in certmonger[1] as it does not return the
full CA chain.

As a workaround, until certmonger is fixed, this change points the
InternalTLSVncCAFile to /etc/ipa/ca.crt which has the full CA chain.

[1] - https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1710632

Change-Id: I750c5572505ff58b8164906754f1bcaf4fd256e0
(cherry picked from commit fc914e96116532985fef5b7e02e1dbbc8842f81e)

and tests, and that the current dev release is enabled

commit_message:
Distribute direct charm dependencies

Do not rely on system installed Python packages but distribute the
direct charm dependencies as part of the charms wheelhouse.

As the span of distributions we need to support with reactive
charms widens we will run into compability problems with the
current model.

For further reference see juju/charm-helpers#341 and
juju-solutions/layer-basic#135

Fix charm locations in functional test bundles.

Change-Id: I7ad4b548669989f778c604addb1aa873f958a5f9

commit_message:
Distribute direct charm dependencies

Do not rely on system installed Python packages but distribute the
direct charm dependencies as part of the charms wheelhouse.

As the span of distributions we need to support with reactive
charms widens we will run into compability problems with the
current model.

For further reference see juju/charm-helpers#341 and
juju-solutions/layer-basic#135

Update domain name uesd in ``.gitreview``.

Change-Id: Ib8476c72020c0a1fbb2549c3ceeafac7f12f3efe

commit_message:
Allows to disable in-flight validations

Up to now, the in-flight validations were launched without any way to
deactivate them. This patch intends to change that fact.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/675823
Change-Id: Ic3af7eb49ee6db5bc0ab10302c3f2a2c616db7b6
(cherry picked from commit 32e53e60596094290298ffd9f9e6be754fd21825)

commit_message:
nova: Stop setting '[DEFAULT] use_ipv6'

Change I188fc2cd1b26fe7a71804f7e7d66b111d6f15e30 in nova stopped us
respecting this when generating the network templates injected into
instances on boot. With the removal of nova-network, there is no longer
any other reason to set this.

Change-Id: I925b7c6c23133cd5a835960f4507c979f615d78e
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2019-05-22 14:21:21.000000000', 'message': "Allow first address in an IPv6 subnet as valid unicast

When looking at the RFC [1], there's no mention that this can't be the
gateway address.  Permit it.

[1] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4291#section-2.6.1

Change-Id: I3f2905c2c4fca02406dfa3c801c166c14389ba41
Fixes-Bug: #1682094
(cherry picked from commit 1916bc5c0627ca24e312ca55ea62c8df7eb8f158)
"}, {'created': '2019-05-24 21:42:11.000000000', 'message': "Allow first address in an IPv6 subnet as valid unicast

When looking at the RFC [1], there's no mention that this can't be the
gateway address.  Permit it.

[1] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4291#section-2.6.1

Change-Id: I3f2905c2c4fca02406dfa3c801c166c14389ba41
Fixes-Bug: #1682094

"}]
commit_message:
Allow first address in an IPv6 subnet as valid unicast

When looking at the RFC [1], there's no mention that this can't be the
gateway address.  Permit it.

[1] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4291#section-2.6.1

Change-Id: I3f2905c2c4fca02406dfa3c801c166c14389ba41
Fixes-Bug: #1682094
(cherry picked from commit 1916bc5c0627ca24e312ca55ea62c8df7eb8f158)

commit_message:
Break out hostname format logic into functions

The consequence of this changing behaviour is nodes being replaced,
so this code really needs some dedicated unit tests.

Change-Id: I6fd00a16e93087759dc964734a81dbd2d31815dd
Blueprint: nova-less-deploy

commit_message:
Add certmonger-grafana-refresh script

Following the pattern of the other openstack components,
we need the refresh script that trigger a restart of the
ceph grafana container when the certificate gets renewed.
This commit adds also the postsave_cmd in the ceph_grafana
puppet file to reflect the the change.

Change-Id: I91df82eec1715bd7a9d0b1ac44f72dd76f9e54cd

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-08 23:47:31.000000000', 'message': "DNM proposed change to baremetal provision format

This is just the schema changes for a proposed evolution of the
baremetal provision yaml format. Once an agreement is made I can update
this change for the code to consume this format.

The changes are:
- instance properties are split into reserve and provision properties
  to make their purpose clear
- a top-level instance_defaults mirrors an instance entry, to be used
  when building instances by count (code based validation will be added
  to ensure name/hostname are not used here)
- image properties are moved to there own object to avoid needing the
  image_ prefix (I'm not strongly attached to this one)

Change-Id: Iad675e5b5e3b4614ecd53d3d729986be52a469d1
Blueprint: nova-less-deploy

commit_message:
Changes to baremetal provision format

The changes are:
- a top-level 'defaults' mirrors an instance entry, to be
  used when building instances by count, and to set defaults for
  instance entries (code based validation is added to ensure
  name/hostname are not used here)
- image properties are moved to there own object to avoid needing
  the image_ prefix
- make ExpandRolesAction responsible for setting defaults for
  instance entries so they don't need to be set each time validate
  is called

Change-Id: Iad675e5b5e3b4614ecd53d3d729986be52a469d1
Blueprint: nova-less-deploy

messages:
[{'account_id': 28691, 'date': '2019-07-29 01:39:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 22623, 'date': '2019-07-29 02:57:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 25564, 'date': '2019-07-29 03:53:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 27488, 'date': '2019-07-29 05:24:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 27224, 'date': '2019-07-29 16:07:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

This change is fine as a safety precaution.  But you should also try to configure your health policy using a higher value for node_update_timeout (https://docs.openstack.org/senlin/latest/user/policy_types/health.html#properties)

node_update_timeout is the time in seconds the health policy waits after a node operation (e.g. scale out or resize) before it tries to check the node health.  So you should set it to a little longer than it takes a VM to start up.'}, {'account_id': 28691, 'date': '2019-07-31 02:31:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> This change is fine as a safety precaution.  But you should also
 > try to configure your health policy using a higher value for
 > node_update_timeout (https://docs.openstack.org/senlin/latest/user/policy_types/health.html#properties)
 > 
 > node_update_timeout is the time in seconds the health policy waits
 > after a node operation (e.g. scale out or resize) before it tries
 > to check the node health.  So you should set it to a little longer
 > than it takes a VM to start up.

Yes, i think we could do that. But, i don't want do increase wait time because the detection failed node maybe slower"}, {'account_id': 28691, 'date': '2019-07-31 09:30:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 27224, 'date': '2019-08-02 16:46:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Yes, i think we could do that. But, i don't want do increase wait
 > time because the detection failed node maybe slower

The node_update_timeout value is only used to wait for the node to become ready for health checks after it has been recovered.  This value does not affect detection interval which is tells the health manager how often to check a node for health status.  node_update_timeout is the same as health check grace period in AWS: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/autoscaling/ec2/userguide/healthcheck.html#health-check-grace-period"}, {'account_id': 27224, 'date': '2019-08-02 18:26:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 30356, 'date': '2019-08-11 14:08:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 27781, 'date': '2019-08-14 15:09:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 28743, 'date': '2019-08-14 16:10:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 27224, 'date': '2019-08-19 16:34:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 22998, 'date': '2019-08-20 17:42:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

commit_message:
Fix error when senlin do health check a cluster

When cluster doing resize/scale create nodes, and physcical id of this nodes
not found. And cluster was attached a policy health check will do health check cluster.
So on, cluster being recover that nodes and emit error log on senlin-engine.log

Change-Id: Icece85bd60faa8b9f2fd18bfe953ebeed91f0091

commit_message:
Add rhel_containers variable

For skipping containers that are not ready to be deployed
on RHEL, add rhel_containers variable, it will disable containers
generation in tripleo-common/container-images/overcloud_containers.yaml.j2
See patch: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/676497/

tracked by tripleo-ci squad in [1]
[1] https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/task/1154

subject: Restrict release-wheel-mirror job to master
messages: [{'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2019-08-20 18:04:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-08-20 18:06:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-08-20 18:15:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1\n\nThis should be fine because the wheel mirror is there specifically to build wheels for OpenStack dependencies which don't already publish one to PyPI. The only dependencies which should be changing in OpenStack's stable branches would be patch-level point releases of OpenStack libraries, and those get auto-built wheels uploaded to PyPI at the time they release. Everything else was already built against master before it was frozen to create a new stable branch."}]

Build and publish jobs for the wheel mirror only run against
master. Restrict the release job to master as well to avoid zuul

Without this we get many config error'd periodic stable jobs because
release-wheel-mirror cannot run its build and publish dependencies.

Change-Id: I6f26fe0e3451c07e6ea4f5267e28c014c6ba1ca8
"}]
commit_message:
Restrict release-wheel-mirror job to master

Build and publish jobs for the wheel mirror only run against
master. Restrict the release job to master as well to avoid zuul
config errors due to stable branches not being able to run their
job depenendencies.

Without this we get many config error'd periodic stable jobs because
release-wheel-mirror cannot run its build and publish dependencies.

Change-Id: I6f26fe0e3451c07e6ea4f5267e28c014c6ba1ca8

commit_message:
Add 'openstack server resize (confirm|revert)' commands

These are currently exposed as flags on the 'openstack server resize'
command but they are in fact operation and should be exposed as commands
in their own right.

The old flag-based variants are deprecated for removal in 4.0.

Change-Id: I733796d3bda6c3755a3d3548bbe695abb474a6a0
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-07 15:25:17.000000000', 'message': 'Enable staging-ovirt (fence_rhevm) fencing agent.

This commit extends actions/parameters to generate
fencing parameters for nodes using staging-ovirt (fence_rhevm).

Given instackenv.json content like:

{
  "nodes":[
{
  "name":"ctrl01",
  "pm_type":"staging-ovirt",
  "mac": [
"56:6f:71:33:00:0d"
  ],
  "arch": "x86_64",
  "pm_user":"admin@internal",
  "pm_password":"redhat",
  "pm_addr":"10.0.0.141",
  "pm_vm_name":"ctrl01"
}
...

Here the generated fence.yaml:

parameter_defaults:
  EnableFencing: true
  FencingConfig:
    devices:
    - agent: fence_rhevm
      host_mac: 56:6f:71:33:00:0d
      params:
        ipaddr: 10.0.0.141
        login: admin@internal
        passwd: redhat
        port: ctrl01
        ssl: 1
        ssl_insecure: 1

And the resulting pacemaker stonith resource:

stonith-fence_rhevm-566f7133000d        (stonith:fence_rhevm:(  Started overcloud-controller-1

To have this working 'out of the box' we assume the worst case
scenario of ovirt-engine using a self-signed certificate, so
we explicitly ssl_insecure=1.
Users/Operators should be aware of this and eventually adjust
the value accordingly.

Change-Id: I3b746eff8367133cec2c6ff03aad25993d26e90c
(cherry picked from commit c13c9cf5a2e26b4a27fabc454d99d3643ba3dd42)
'}]
commit_message:
Enable staging-ovirt (fence_rhevm) fencing agent.

This commit extends actions/parameters to generate
fencing parameters for nodes using staging-ovirt (fence_rhevm).

Given instackenv.json content like:

{
  "nodes":[
{
  "name":"ctrl01",
  "pm_type":"staging-ovirt",
  "mac": [
"56:6f:71:33:00:0d"
  ],
  "arch": "x86_64",
  "pm_user":"admin@internal",
  "pm_password":"redhat",
  "pm_addr":"10.0.0.141",
  "pm_vm_name":"ctrl01"
}
...

Here the generated fence.yaml:

parameter_defaults:
  EnableFencing: true
  FencingConfig:
    devices:
    - agent: fence_rhevm
      host_mac: 56:6f:71:33:00:0d
      params:
        ipaddr: 10.0.0.141
        login: admin@internal
        passwd: redhat
        port: ctrl01
        ssl: 1
        ssl_insecure: 1

And the resulting pacemaker stonith resource:

stonith-fence_rhevm-566f7133000d        (stonith:fence_rhevm:(  Started overcloud-controller-1

To have this working 'out of the box' we assume the worst case
scenario of ovirt-engine using a self-signed certificate, so
we explicitly ssl_insecure=1.
Users/Operators should be aware of this and eventually adjust
the value accordingly.

Change-Id: I3b746eff8367133cec2c6ff03aad25993d26e90c
(cherry picked from commit c13c9cf5a2e26b4a27fabc454d99d3643ba3dd42)

The <id> portion of a --block-device-mapping value can be
the resource name or id since the code uses the appropriate
type-specific find_resource utility to lookup the resource
based on the value given.

This change simply fixes the description of <id> to mention
it's name or id rather than just "UUID". My guess is the
description was originally copied from novaclient where id
must be an id since name resolution does not happen in novaclient.

Change-Id: I567f6f6efb3a3b6d387133d21aa81354b2d753bc

commit_message:
Fix <id> description for --block-device-mapping

The <id> portion of a --block-device-mapping value can be
the resource name or id since the code uses the appropriate
type-specific find_resource utility to lookup the resource
based on the value given.

This change simply fixes the description of <id> to mention
it's name or id rather than just "UUID". My guess is the
description was originally copied from novaclient where id
must be an id since name resolution does not happen in novaclient.

Change-Id: I567f6f6efb3a3b6d387133d21aa81354b2d753bc

This adds a --boot-from-volume option to the server create
command which is used with the --image or --image-property
option and will create a volume-backed server from the
specified image with the specified size. Similar to the
--volume option, the created root volume will not be deleted
when the server is deleted. The --boot-from-volume option
is not allowed with the --volume option since they both create
a block device mapping with boot_index=0.

commit_message:
Add openstack server create --boot-from-volume option

This adds a --boot-from-volume option to the server create
command which is used with the --image or --image-property
option and will create a volume-backed server from the
specified image with the specified size. Similar to the
--volume option, the created root volume will not be deleted
when the server is deleted. The --boot-from-volume option
is not allowed with the --volume option since they both create
a block device mapping with boot_index=0.

Change-Id: I88c590361cb232c1df7b5bb010dcea307080d34c
Story: 2006302
Task: 36017

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-17 06:44:43.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Create Seagate driver from dothill driver

This patch creates a new 'supported' driver for Seagate (STX) FC and
iSCSI arrays by renaming and re-enabling the old 'unsupported' dothill
driver.  Other than marking the driver as 'supported', this patch
contains no changes in functionality.

Other drivers which referenced the dothill driver are modified to use
the Seagate class names, so users of those drivers will not be affected.

Change-Id: I3115ae296ae6b5702c7a8fa39249b8735542e17e
"}, {'created': '2019-07-18 05:13:10.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Create Seagate driver from dothill driver

This patch creates a new 'supported' driver for Seagate (STX) FC and
iSCSI arrays by renaming and re-enabling the old 'unsupported' dothill
driver.  Other than marking the driver as 'supported', this patch
contains no changes in functionality.

Other drivers which referenced the dothill driver are modified to use
the Seagate class names, so users of those drivers will not be affected.

Change-Id: I3115ae296ae6b5702c7a8fa39249b8735542e17e
"}, {'created': '2019-07-21 20:02:42.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Create Seagate driver from dothill driver

commit_message:
Create Seagate driver from dothill driver

This patch creates a new 'supported' driver for Seagate (STX) FC and
iSCSI arrays by renaming and re-enabling the old 'unsupported' dothill
driver.  Other than marking the driver as 'supported', this patch
contains no changes in functionality except for multiattach fixes from
change I47f02729437cabab92ccc553a4c60d0c0a796952 needed to pass CI and
deprecation of vendor-specific options requested by the core team.

Other drivers which referenced the dothill driver are modified to use
the Seagate class names, so users of those drivers will not be affected
except for option-deprecation warnings.

Change-Id: I3115ae296ae6b5702c7a8fa39249b8735542e17e

As usual I edited the release note :)

Matt, do you want to say something about the caveat with vda that you've noted in the release note so users have a chance to find that?  Or is it enough of an edge case that it is not necessary to do that?"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-08-09 16:42:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Matt, do you want to say something about the caveat with vda that you've noted in the release note so users have a chance to find that?  Or is it enough of an edge case that it is not necessary to do that?

I think specifying --image and an image bdm with vda is an edge case and the error message from the API is clear enough if you do it that I think trying to document it in a release note isn't really worth it - it would probably cause more confusion than it would help. Also, a release note likely wouldn't be seen by someone later anyway. If it is a source of confusion for people, then I think we'd mention something in the option description."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2019-08-20 16:09:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-29 17:03:11.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Support type=image with --block-device-mapping option

TODO:
- figure out what to do about --image conflicts
- tests
- release note

The --block-device-mapping option on the server create
command currently only supports booting from volume and
volume snapshot. A common boot-from-volume scenario is
providing an image and letting nova orchestrate the
creation of the image-backed volume and attaching it to
the server.

This adds support for type=image in the --block-device-mapping
option. The volume size is requird in this case. Note that
the CLI currently says if type=snapshot that size is also required
but that's technically not true. When booting from a volume
snapshot, the compute API will use the size of the volume snapshot
to create the volume if an explicit size is not provided. For the
purposes of this patch, we need the size anyway for the image
being the block device mapping source type.

Change-Id: I57b3c261d8309f7b9f62a3e91612bce592a887a3
Story: 2006302
Task: 36016

commit_message:
Support type=image with --block-device-mapping option

The --block-device-mapping option on the server create
command currently only supports booting from volume and
volume snapshot. A common boot-from-volume scenario is
providing an image and letting nova orchestrate the
creation of the image-backed volume and attaching it to
the server.

This adds support for type=image in the --block-device-mapping
option. The volume size is required in this case. Note that
the CLI currently says if type=snapshot that size is also required
but that's technically not true. When booting from a volume
snapshot, the compute API will use the size of the volume snapshot
to create the volume if an explicit size is not provided. For the
purposes of this patch, we need the size anyway for the image
being the block device mapping source type.

Change-Id: I57b3c261d8309f7b9f62a3e91612bce592a887a3
Story: 2006302
Task: 36016

commit_message:
Fix formatting of lists of commands in release notes

Without markup to generate a list, multiple commands are rendered on the
same line.

Change-Id: Ibc6d55c653a3d3f6523af42e7960cfc649989c9d

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 20466, 'date': '2019-07-27 05:14:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> (1 comment)

Per the link in the documentation:  Note that the JSON spec doesn’t support octal notation, so use the value 256 for 0400 permissions. If you use yaml instead of json for the pod, you can use octal notation to specify permissions in a more natural way. 

Can we not then use the octal notation since we are using yaml?'}, {'account_id': 22636, 'date': '2019-07-27 13:01:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 22636, 'date': '2019-07-27 16:01:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I've played around with this a bit today, and found that when you use yaml, it accepts both ways. Add a "0" in front if you want to use octal, and just use three digits for decimal.  So "365" in decimal and "0555" have the same effect. Same goes for defaultMode in configMaps as well.'}, {'account_id': 20466, 'date': '2019-07-30 15:41:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> I've played around with this a bit today, and found that when you
 > use yaml, it accepts both ways. Add a "0" in front if you want to
 > use octal, and just use three digits for decimal.  So "365" in
 > decimal and "0555" have the same effect. Same goes for defaultMode
 > in configMaps as well.

If it makes no difference I think 0555 might be better than 365 as most are familiar with the Linux permission bit rather than the decimal 365.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-07-30 16:03:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I have to think about it in more details. Thanks for the patch, I like the idea at first sight.'}, {'account_id': 29668, 'date': '2019-07-30 16:09:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Enhance HTK Job Manifests to be more flexible

This patch enhances the HTK job manifest functions so that each job can
be configured to use the desired backoffLimit and activeDeadlineSeconds,
and can mount the command/script from either a configMap or a secret
instead of being confined to using only configMaps.

Change-Id: I5231e53b98e3e55e3e93070876d8694f37ad642d

commit_message:
Nagios: Updated the plugin to handle warnings

The plugin only trigerred Critical for any type of Severity fired from the
Prometheus alerts.
Now the code is updated to handle the Prometheus alert of severity=warning
along with severity=page.
This should help in alarm tuning in Prometheus and Nagios.

Change-Id: I89c1880ab05b896590391db611354b069ade363a

recheck'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2019-08-01 21:15:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2019-08-01 21:23:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2019-08-01 21:53:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

When the health check tried to run 'ceph osd stat' it failed because it could not access /etc/ceph/ceph.conf [1]. This is because that file doesn't exist, instead mycephcluster.conf existed [2]. This is because this was passing 'CephClusterName: mycephcluster' which results in the /etc/ceph/{CephClusterName}.conf being created. It seems the nautilus container cannot handle that. We can workaround this by not using a custom name but this job has pointed out that the customer names seem broken.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/45/673545/1/check/tripleo-ci-centos-7-scenario010-multinode-oooq-container/be09634/logs/undercloud/var/lib/mistral/config-download-latest/ansible.log.txt.gz#_2019-07-30_21_15_24_743

commit_message:
Update series metadata

Ensure that EOL releases are removed from metadata
and tests, and that the current dev release is enabled
in metadata.  Dev release tests are enabled separately
because of chickens and eggs.

Change-Id: I2d83b5a98e82f3120952178494884f3f1e3ca2b9

[{'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-05-22 10:30:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-05-24 08:46:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Review-Priority+1

Tests will fail unless dependent glance-store patch is merged and new version is released.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-06-04 05:42:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-06-04 05:43:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Review-Priority+1'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-06-10 06:29:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-06-18 04:55:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-06-18 05:23:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-06-18 05:58:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-06-18 08:57:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Review-Priority+1'}, {'account_id': 28595, 'date': '2019-07-11 06:41:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

get_store_id_from_uri function will only verify the scheme of the backend, not if the file is really present, this would lead to an error if you use multiple backend of the same type (ex: 2 rbd backend). if the file is on the second backend, so the first one will be returned by your function, and glance will still trigger a 400 Invalid location when trying to effectively check the file later in the process.

I recommend to use :
"get_size_from_uri_and_backend(url, backend)" from glance_store instead, as it would really check the size of the file in the backend, and trigger an error is not found.

For me we need to look more at https://review.opendev.org/#/c/618932/2'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-07-11 07:00:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> get_store_id_from_uri function will only verify the scheme of the
 > backend, not if the file is really present, this would lead to an
 > error if you use multiple backend of the same type (ex: 2 rbd
 > backend). if the file is on the second backend, so the first one
 > will be returned by your function, and glance will still trigger a
 > 400 Invalid location when trying to effectively check the file
 > later in the process.
 > 
 > I recommend to use :
 > "get_size_from_uri_and_backend(url, backend)" from glance_store
 > instead, as it would really check the size of the file in the
 > backend, and trigger an error is not found.
 > 
 > For me we need to look more at https://review.opendev.org/#/c/618932/2

Hi Victor,

This get_store_id_from_uri is not just matching with scheme it is actually matching entire url with the '_url_prefix ' of each store, have a look at [1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/660340'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-07-11 07:14:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6: Patch Set 5 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-07-11 09:40:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-07-19 13:34:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Two things:

(1) something to look at noted inline

(2) I was reading over Victor's comment, and while I think you are correct about the rbd case, from looking at https://review.opendev.org/#/c/660340/, it looks like Victor would be right about at least the http store and the cinder store (I didn't look through all of them).  Maybe configuring multiple http stores is a weird case (though I'm not convinced of that), but I can see someone using multiple cinder stores.  I think this lazy update needs to be more robust."}, {'account_id': 28595, 'date': '2019-07-19 15:28:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Too more things to say (sorry for that):
- Can't we put the lazy_update_store_info() in a utils function ? Because it is exactly the same code as the _update_store_in_location() function in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/660645 (I will move my test then)
- I agree that the RBD store should be ok with the url_prefix comparaison, but in case of ceph cluster not available at glance boot time, so you will return only "rbd://" as url_prefix, and you will have get the issue I explain previously, even though the ceph cluster is back online since. Does this code executed only at glance boot time or at every request ?'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-07-22 05:03:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> Too more things to say (sorry for that):

 > comparaison, but in case of ceph cluster not available at glance
 > boot time, so you will return only "rbd://" as url_prefix, and you
 > will have get the issue I explain previously, even though the ceph
 > cluster is back online since. Does this code executed only at
 > glance boot time or at every request ?
Hi Victor,

The _url_prefix will be set while initializing the stores. Stores are initialized at the time of boot as well as post, update, delete  requests as well. I have tested this with 2 ceph nodes and never encountered the issue you have mentioned.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-07-22 05:07:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> (1 comment)

 > it looks like Victor would be right about at least the http store
 > and the cinder store (I didn't look through all of them).  Maybe
 > configuring multiple http stores is a weird case (though I'm not
 > convinced of that), but I can see someone using multiple cinder
 > stores.  I think this lazy update needs to be more robust.

Hi Brian,

You are right, for cinder and http stores this can be problematic only in case of locations operation. This lazy update function is robust at the moment. In order to support cinder and http multiple stores for add/replace location case we need to change the driver implementation and append a uuid to each store instead of just creating the url prefix like cinder:// and http://. Also we need to change the consumer side like cinder or nova as well."}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-07-22 05:11:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Published edit on patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-07-22 05:13:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

commit_message:
Lazy update stores information

Added new decorator around get image call which will add
or update store inforamtion to location metadata if it
is not available.

Implements: blueprint lazy-update-stores
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/660340/
Change-Id: I51b6afad56cfa5ccf6c6584bb33e83ce34b4387d

subject: Prevent unnecessary nova-compute restarts on ceph_changed
messages:
[{'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-08-14 13:02:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-08-14 13:28:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

charm-recheck-full'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-08-16 18:40:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-08-16 18:43:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-08-16 18:54:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Complementing the reasoning for doing this:

1) we would like to backport this change. Refactoring now nova-compute + charmhelpers would make the change riskier to backport and would also affect backports of other charms due to necessary charmhelpers syncing.

2) Patchset #1 is an alternative solution with less code changed. The problem with that solution is that it relies on the chance of ceph_changed invocation with the broker remote unit context. If for some reason that does not happen, is disrupted or fails for any other reason, it is harder to workaround. The previous code relied on that for is_broker_action_done and mark_broker_action_done, but is_request_complete and is_request_sent were already iterating on all units to find the broker_rsp, just like we are doing now. Therefore the current solution (Patchset #3) is safer and more predictable, as any unit will be able to process the broker response.'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-08-16 19:17:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-08-16 20:02:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

charm-recheck-full'}, {'account_id': 20635, 'date': '2019-08-17 02:13:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Thank you for your work on this.  I'd prefer to see the c-h bits done along with this, rather than introduce new code that we know will need to be refactored."}, {'account_id': 20635, 'date': '2019-08-19 15:56:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: -Code-Review

Per cross-team conversation, we are lifting the -1 on this tactical fix due to the need for a rapid back-port fix to stable, and with the commitment to do the refactoring in charm-helpers as a separate effort, following this work.'}, {'account_id': 20805, 'date': '2019-08-19 16:11:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

Thanks for this work. And thank you for the well-documented code.'}, {'account_id': 20634, 'date': '2019-08-19 16:15:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

I have a minor preference for putting the new helpers into the utils file, rather than the hooks file, but I'm generally happy with this change. Given that the code in question needs to be migrated to charmhelpers as well in a broader refactoring change, I'm OK with the non-ideal state here."}, {'account_id': 14567, 'date': '2019-08-20 17:09:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Cherry Picked

This patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/19.07 as commit 0608952687038b208f706329aa6fe22b928b1074'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-14 13:02:53.000000000', 'message': 'Prevent unnecessary nova-compute restarts on ceph_changed

Function is_broker_action_done returns False if there
is no response data from ceph broker. In that case, it ends up
causing nova-compute service restarts while it should only do
so when there is a response and it verifies as the action not
being marked as done.

Adding a separate check prevents that ambiguous behavior from
causing unnecessary nova-compute restarts.

Change-Id: I2b41f8b252f4ccb68830e90c5e68456e15372bcf
Closes-bug: #1835045
'}, {'created': '2019-08-16 18:40:54.000000000', 'message': "Prevent unnecessary nova-compute restarts on ceph_changed

Function 'is_broker_action_done' should return False when it
finds a response from ceph broker not marked done, in order
to trigger a nova restart. However, it also returns False if
there is no response data from ceph broker, triggering an
unecessary restart.

The function 'ceph_changed' is invoked under different remote
unit contexts when there are updates to the relation. When
querying the broker response, only the context of the remote
unit that is the broker can see the response, unless
specifically queried for that given unit.

The 'ceph_changed' invocations under a remote context that
are not the broker end up returning False in
'is_broker_action_done' and causing restarts, even after
the action is already marked done. This also happens on
'config-changed' hooks.

To fix this problem, the logic is now changed have each
'ceph_changed' invocation loop through units and process
the broker response, regardless of remote context.

This is an initial change to address the issue locally
in nova-compute charm. A later change will be worked on
to move the new helper methods to charmhelpers,
refactoring the existing ones there.

Change-Id: I2b41f8b252f4ccb68830e90c5e68456e15372bcf
Closes-bug: #1835045

commit_message:
Prevent unnecessary nova-compute restarts on ceph_changed

Function 'is_broker_action_done' should return False when it
finds a response from ceph broker not marked done, in order
to trigger a nova restart. However, it also returns False if
there is no response data from ceph broker, triggering an
unecessary restart.

The function 'ceph_changed' is invoked under different remote
unit contexts when there are updates to the relation. When
querying the broker response, only the context of the remote
unit that is the broker can see the response, unless
specifically queried for that given unit.

The 'ceph_changed' invocations under a remote context that
are not the broker end up returning False in
'is_broker_action_done' and causing restarts, even after
the action is already marked done. This also happens on
'config-changed' hooks.

To fix this problem, the logic is now changed have each
'ceph_changed' invocation loop through units and process
the broker response, regardless of remote context.

This is an initial change to address the issue locally
in nova-compute charm. A later change will be worked on
to move the new helper methods to charmhelpers,
refactoring the existing ones there.

Change-Id: I2b41f8b252f4ccb68830e90c5e68456e15372bcf
Closes-bug: #1835045

commit_message:
Change location metadata key 'backend' to 'store'

As a part of vocabulary correction, changed the location
metadata key name from 'backend' to 'store'. Modified
corresponding tests as well.

bp:multi-store-vocabulary-correction
Change-Id: Iae3503cba6be362b372e1fc3e75c2ddb1e99b763
