commit_message:
Ensure Barbican required roles are created by Keystone

Presently there are several roles: audit, observer, and key-manger:
service-admin that are used in Barbican policy but not generated
by Keystone during a TripleO Deployment.

This change updates Keystone's manifest to include creation of these
missing roles then the Barbican API is included as part of a depl-
oyment.

Change-Id: I6d5d0a37abeb54600bb70e22fabde9479320ab81

commit_message:
Configure keystone_authtoken/service_token_roles

This patch introduces a new hieradata to configure service_token_roles
in keystone authtoken middleware configuration, so that we can use
a customized role for user who uses service token feature.

Change-Id: Ife07d55390390e9dd62fe4df0393010b9aa40030

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/674104/3 : FAILURE in 2h 15m 14s'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-08-05 16:47:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I get the utility of this and why you're doing it. Personally, I think this adds confusion and tech debt for minimal gain. It makes it easy to kick that debt down the road, encourages others to do the same, and it makes it more confusing (IMHO, of course) to see what fields are real and not when looking at the object definition. For example, someone using an object like this has to know that if they need to obj.obj_reset_changes(), they have to use the real name of the field instead of the one used elsewhere in their code. Similarly for checking dirty-ness, and is-it-set-ness.

So, personally, I'd rather not see us do this. I know bumping to 2.0 is work (TBH, not sure it's that much more than this, FWIW), but it has a defined end date and doesn't encourage others to just paper over stuff.

But, get opinions from others for sure."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-08-06 09:52:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
objects: Add proxy fields to NUMATopology object

The names for these are getting super convoluted now. Add a 'ProxyField'
field type, based on the 'ProxyDictField' from o.vo, and use this to
provide the following aliases:

  cpuset      -> shared_cpus
  pcpuset     -> dedicated_cpus
  cpu_usage   -> shared_cpus_usage
  pinned_cpus -> dedicated_cpus_usage

This is big but only because almost every reference to those old fields
has been updated to use the new, sensible names.

Change-Id: If125ba8c625e71fc67eb86c38390bc58e7924732
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-15 16:02:19.000000000', 'message': '3PAR: Provide new option to specify NSP for single path attachments

This fix aims to resolve below mentioned bugs:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/os-brick/+bug/1812665
https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1809249
https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1734917

Given a system connected to HPE 3PAR via FC and multipath is disabled.
When user tries to create bootable volume, it fails intermittently
with following error:
Fibre Channel volume device not found

This happens when a zone is created using second or later target nsp
from 3PAR backend.
In this case, HPE 3PAR client code picks up first target nsp to form
initiator target map.

To avoid above mentioned failure, user can specify target nsp in 3PAR
backend section of cinder.conf as follows:

hpe3par_target_nsp = <n:s:p>

This target information is read from cinder.conf and respective
wwn information is fetched.
Later initiator target map is created using wwn information and
bootable volume is created successfully.

Change-Id: If77d384afbc7097ed55a03e9b4bc7f8e1966a5c5
Closes bug: #1809249
(cherry picked from commit b7c81a7b426136314fb12f5aafcb977b25d49cc6)
'}]
commit_message:
3PAR: Provide new option to specify NSP for single path attachments

This fix aims to resolve below mentioned bugs:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/os-brick/+bug/1812665
https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1809249
https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1734917

Given a system connected to HPE 3PAR via FC and multipath is disabled.
When user tries to create bootable volume, it fails intermittently
with following error:
Fibre Channel volume device not found

This happens when a zone is created using second or later target nsp
from 3PAR backend.
In this case, HPE 3PAR client code picks up first target nsp to form
initiator target map.

To avoid above mentioned failure, user can specify target nsp in 3PAR
backend section of cinder.conf as follows:

hpe3par_target_nsp = <n:s:p>

This target information is read from cinder.conf and respective
wwn information is fetched.
Later initiator target map is created using wwn information and
bootable volume is created successfully.

Change-Id: If77d384afbc7097ed55a03e9b4bc7f8e1966a5c5
Closes bug: #1809249
(cherry picked from commit b7c81a7b426136314fb12f5aafcb977b25d49cc6)

3PAR: Provide new option to specify NSP for single path attachments

This fix aims to resolve below mentioned bugs:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/os-brick/+bug/1812665
https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1809249
https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1734917

Given a system connected to HPE 3PAR via FC and multipath is disabled.
When user tries to create bootable volume, it fails intermittently
with following error:
Fibre Channel volume device not found

This happens when a zone is created using second or later target nsp
from 3PAR backend.
In this case, HPE 3PAR client code picks up first target nsp to form
initiator target map.

To avoid above mentioned failure, user can specify target nsp in 3PAR
backend section of cinder.conf as follows:

hpe3par_target_nsp = <n:s:p>

This target information is read from cinder.conf and respective
wwn information is fetched.
Later initiator target map is created using wwn information and
bootable volume is created successfully.

Change-Id: If77d384afbc7097ed55a03e9b4bc7f8e1966a5c5
Closes bug: #1809249
(cherry picked from commit b7c81a7b426136314fb12f5aafcb977b25d49cc6)

commit_message:
WIP! Stop passing 'root_helper' argument to os-brick

It looks like os-brick simply ignores this now [1], so stop passing it.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/os-brick/blob/1c02d52/os_brick/privileged/rootwrap.py#L166

Change-Id: I569325b50140053d27184a5aee3990b054834a89
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Rationalize endpoint_for and get_endpoint_from_catalog

We have two methods in two different places which do almost the
same thing. Make one use the other and then document what they do.
Finally, make sure endpoint_for respects endpoint_override, since
that would be the rational expectation at that point in the code.

Add some tests.

Change-Id: I4ff51373496c558342cfb54820eab4dddd195625

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-11 13:05:23.000000000', 'message': "Fix OOB introspection to use pxe_enabled flag in idrac driver

Baremetal nodes fail to pxe boot during OpenStack deployment.
Reason of this failure is because we are not checking the
actual pxe device interface and updating the port pxe_enabled field.

This patch make sure that everytime when port is created, it checks the
the BIOS and UEFI boot modes of node and fetch the pxe device interfaces
values matching to nic id and then update the port's pxe_enabled field.

Change-Id: I2890bf16110b713e269d4a4fe410f57273dc8e83
Story: 2004340
(cherry picked from commit 2b74d940c932c1bb4498f47372c0545e4480799f)
"}, {'created': '2019-01-03 08:35:48.000000000', 'message': "Fix OOB introspection to use pxe_enabled flag in idrac driver

Baremetal nodes fail to pxe boot during OpenStack deployment.
Reason of this failure is because we are not checking the actual
pxe device interface and updating the port pxe_enabled field.

This patch make sure that everytime when port is created, it checks the
the BIOS and UEFI boot modes of node and fetch the pxe device interfaces
values matching to nic id and then update the port's pxe_enabled field.

Change-Id: I2890bf16110b713e269d4a4fe410f57273dc8e83
Story: 2004340
(cherry picked from commit 2b74d940c932c1bb4498f47372c0545e4480799f)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix OOB introspection to use pxe_enabled flag in idrac driver

Baremetal nodes fail to pxe boot during OpenStack deployment.
Reason of this failure is because we are not checking the actual
pxe device interface and updating the port pxe_enabled field.

This patch make sure that everytime when port is created, it checks the
the BIOS and UEFI boot modes of node and fetch the pxe device interfaces
values matching to nic id and then update the port's pxe_enabled field.

Change-Id: I2890bf16110b713e269d4a4fe410f57273dc8e83
Story: 2004340
(cherry picked from commit 2b74d940c932c1bb4498f47372c0545e4480799f)

commit_message:
Add iPXE boot interface to 'ilo' hardware type

This commit adds new boot interface 'ilo-ipxe' to support booting
of iPXE instances using 'ilo' hardware type.

Change-Id: I3abebc77cbc57344a74759e0a8b99e8cacac6f6b
Story: 2006408
Task: 36292

Fix docs promote publishing

We need short_name - to publish to cloudkitty and not to
openstack/cloudkitty.

commit_message:
Elasticsearch-s3: Add jq

This adds jq to the elasticsearch-s3 image, providing a means to
further filter any adhoc queries executed from the elasticsearch
client container directly

Change-Id: I99dceb336b8886afacf795ad0801684041691d4a
Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>

Current Bug tracker link mentioned in README file does not exit which
create confusion. I checked and not found any bug tracker for this project.
Removing the incorrect link and mention to raise bug on ML or IRC.

Change-Id: Ifd9375cf09154b4439f2c75ff42103535d271270

commit_message:
Remove the incorrect bug tracker link

Current Bug tracker link mentioned in README file does not exit which
create confusion. I checked and not found any bug tracker for this project.
Removing the incorrect link and mention to raise bug on ML or IRC.

Change-Id: Ifd9375cf09154b4439f2c75ff42103535d271270

commit_message:
Add py37 entry in setup.cfg

Since py37 unit test job is now voting on gate,
adding related entry in setup.cfg

Change-Id: I3d9e775250de72e8b79d2d41fa0fadce54707988

[{'created': '2019-08-19 14:36:00.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "3PAR: Provide new option to specify NSP for single path attachments"

Several issues pointed out in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/676728/ that were
not flagged here that should be fixed before we backport.

This reverts commit b7c81a7b426136314fb12f5aafcb977b25d49cc6.

Change-Id: Ic1c79c0f1c92d34085e09beab1f5112c466c1c16
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "3PAR: Provide new option to specify NSP for single path attachments"

Several issues pointed out in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/676728/ that were
not flagged here that should be fixed before we backport.

This reverts commit b7c81a7b426136314fb12f5aafcb977b25d49cc6.

Change-Id: Ic1c79c0f1c92d34085e09beab1f5112c466c1c16

Updating Ceph 404 URLs

Updating to latest URL. Although this is probably
best double checked as this was quite hard to
find and inconsistent since the website has moved
and changed a lot.

Change-Id: Ia6a1c4ae557853dce7ac4cfa1adc3df774121121

subject: Fix quoting in zuul for tempest plugins
messages:
[{'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-06-27 08:43:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-06-27 08:46:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-06-27 08:59:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

I confirmed horizon-dsvm-tempest-plugin job successfully started in zuul dashboard. This is the gate failure so I am approving this fast.'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-06-27 09:09:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2 Workflow-1

Let's wait fo CI first"}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-06-27 09:10:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm not sure that my fix is correct because I can't test it on my local env"}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-06-27 09:35:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review -Workflow

horizon-dsvm-tempest-plugin passed'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-06-27 10:02:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-06-27 13:31:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> I'm not sure that my fix is correct because I can't test it on my local env

I think this is due to Ansible version.
Ansible requires a proper quote in the recent versions.
We must quote a string in YAML. I am not sure how quote with a single and a double quotation mark affected the job, but I guess a single quote (inside a double quote) is passed as a part of a string and this causes the job failure."}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-07-03 15:04:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks for the details, Akihiro!'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-08-20 15:15:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> > I'm not sure that my fix is correct because I can't test it on my
 > local env
 > 
 > I think this is due to Ansible version.
 > Ansible requires a proper quote in the recent versions.
 > We must quote a string in YAML. I am not sure how quote with a
 > single and a double quotation mark affected the job, but I guess a
 > single quote (inside a double quote) is passed as a part of a
 > string and this causes the job failure.

Yeah, we faced few issue like that in other jobs too. tempest-horizon job is failing on stable branches also, I am backporting this."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-08-20 15:16:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Cherry Picked

This patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/stein as commit 7acbf4149cc5d425ac1dd049fce1a284033213ab'}]

configuration no longer works. This patch removes the excess
quoting.

Change-Id: I4c6c3b1d0e0c38c8130440c2b6c162fd65532179

commit_message:
Fix quoting in zuul for tempest plugins

Something has changed and the quoting used in the zuul jobs
configuration no longer works. This patch removes the excess
quoting.

Change-Id: I4c6c3b1d0e0c38c8130440c2b6c162fd65532179

commit_message:
Remove osops-tools-monitoring-oschecks for RHEL 8

The osops-tools-monitoring-oschecks package is not supported in
RHEL 8.

Change-Id: Ib667087532317548042b406d61517b62659bcf3c

commit_message:
Sync Sphinx requirement

Sync sphinx dependency with global requirements. It caps python 2 since
sphinx 2.0 no longer supports Python 2.7.

commit_message:
Add overcloud deploy parameter to set CinderLVMLoopDeviceSize

Master promotion jobs are failing due to cinder backend being
out of space. This review adjusts the LVM backend up for master
to avoid the 'out of space' problem.

Change-Id: Ib46afdc3ff38b51dd1c608e910436188cd0e5472
Closes-Bug: #1840451

commit_message:
Remove now obsolete publish-jobs

Since openstack-manuals, api-guide, api-ref, and openstack-tox-docs are
now publishing via promote jobs, the publish jobs are not needed
anymore, remove them and the playbooks they used.

Note that publish-openstack-tox-docs is used in a few places, update one
here (requirements) and mark the job as deprecated. Before this one can
be removed, update all users.

Remove the now unused afsdeveloper_secret as well.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/677009
Change-Id: Id8069557d0cf788e6eb469c8141945f89ac462e6

subject: Updated the documentation's rst markup
messages:
[{'account_id': 30844, 'date': '2019-08-20 13:40:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-08-20 13:40:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 23060, 'date': '2019-08-20 13:50:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

[{'created': '2019-08-08 08:56:21.000000000', 'message': 'Fix call to storage.delete() in ScopeEndpoint RPC endpoint

This removes the filters on fetcher and collector in the call to
storage.delete() in the ScopeEndpoint RPC endpoint.

Until now, a filter on the collector and the fetcher were passed to the
function, leading to no match from any point.

Change-Id: I4ad72870da08d9be7c1e0c27a6c89d6d27c49f8e
'}]
commit_message:
Fix call to storage.delete() in ScopeEndpoint RPC endpoint

This removes the filters on fetcher and collector in the call to
storage.delete() in the ScopeEndpoint RPC endpoint.

Until now, a filter on the collector and the fetcher were passed to the
function, leading to no match from any point.

Change-Id: I4ad72870da08d9be7c1e0c27a6c89d6d27c49f8e

commit_message:
Remove neutron-fwaas tempest plugin installation

After [1] and [2], fwaas tempest plugin is integrated in neutron-tempest-plugin
so no additional package installation is needed.

This patch removes old fwaas tempest plugin installation. It keeps the
parameter in the manifest for backward compatibility of manifest using
it.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/643668/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/643662/

Change-Id: If2115f59657a1b6c8c8c1541f8f78f9b9103a885

- adds molecule tests

Since molecule tests are running in docker containers, we can't easily

- adds molecule tests

(cherry picked from commit 6ae16f588e60e7e043380641eb15a18f5dd1b854)

commit_message:
Adds molecule tests to image-serve and correct validation

This patch does two things:
- ensure we don't rely on systemd within the validation itself
- adds molecule tests

Since molecule tests are running in docker containers, we can't easily
use the "systemd" helpers.
This patch makes sure the validation checks if the port is opened, and
if we get a proper answer from the server.

Change-Id: Id9a1a62e0cfff0b5300af41ec6c7a08f05ddf012
(cherry picked from commit 6ae16f588e60e7e043380641eb15a18f5dd1b854)

Latest

stein

rocky

Notice the "../" instead of "../..". This breaks the "latest" link on documents such as https://docs.openstack.org/manila/latest/admin/index.html where "latest" links then to https://docs.openstack.org/manila/latest/latest/ Fix this by using the same logic for latest as for the other versions, there's no need to special case it. commit_message:
Fix version dropdown In subdirectories, the version dropdown is incorrect for the Latest entry, it produces:

Latest

stein

rocky

Notice the "../" instead of "../..". This breaks the "latest" link on documents such as https://docs.openstack.org/manila/latest/admin/index.html where "latest" links then to https://docs.openstack.org/manila/latest/latest/ Fix this by using the same logic for latest as for the other versions, there's no need to special case it. Change-Id: I6b0fe830f764ce7dde24cff9c7b84c6a894ca408

commit_message:
Removes monasca_grafana persistent volume

The monasca_grafana docker volume currently persists across container
builds, causing changes to installed plugins during build to be ignored.
This change deletes the volume entirely and forces plugin changes to be
applied via rebuild.

Change-Id: I36e62235a085e5c1955fdb5ae31f603be8ba69bf
(cherry picked from commit ff8c24d62a9e41cbb2f8f72b8fed1c9d040eb18c)

commit_message:
Removes monasca_grafana persistent volume

The monasca_grafana docker volume currently persists across container
builds, causing changes to installed plugins during build to be ignored.
This change deletes the volume entirely and forces plugin changes to be
applied via rebuild.

Change-Id: I36e62235a085e5c1955fdb5ae31f603be8ba69bf
(cherry picked from commit ff8c24d62a9e41cbb2f8f72b8fed1c9d040eb18c)

subject: Properly notify apache restarts on keystone configuration updates
messages: [{'account_id': 21961, 'date': '2019-07-08 01:38:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 21961, 'date': '2019-07-08 02:10:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 19193, 'date': '2019-07-15 10:07:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-08-06 10:11:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:\n\nrecheck'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2019-08-20 12:22:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-08 01:38:54.000000000', 'message': 'Properly notify apache restarts on keystone configuration updates

This uses edit_resource to add a notification in the identity apache
configuration when it gets updated. This is a workaround due to the fact
we are using a version of the apache2 cookbook that is still using
definitions and cannot add notifications with definitions.

This is intended to ensure we only restart apache when the configuration
is updated. Otherwise, the old behaviour was to restart apache on every
run which is problematic in production environments. I have been using
this in our production wrapper cookbook for the past year or so without
any issue.

This will be removed in the Stein release when we migrate to the newer
apache2 cookbook which uses proper resources.

Change-Id: I13de063d1e7ffd356d754eb0f2d8286a3c694836
Signed-off-by: Lance Albertson <lance@osuosl.org>
'}, {'created': '2019-07-08 02:10:58.000000000', 'message': 'Properly notify apache restarts on keystone configuration updates

This uses edit_resource to add a notification in the identity apache
configuration when it gets updated. This is a workaround due to the fact
we are using a version of the apache2 cookbook that is still using
definitions and cannot add notifications with definitions.

This is intended to ensure we only restart apache when the configuration
is updated. Otherwise, the old behaviour was to restart apache on every
run which is problematic in production environments. I have been using
this in our production wrapper cookbook for the past year or so without
any issue.

This will be removed in the Stein release when we migrate to the newer
apache2 cookbook which uses proper resources.

Change-Id: I13de063d1e7ffd356d754eb0f2d8286a3c694836
Signed-off-by: Lance Albertson <lance@osuosl.org>
'}]
commit_message:
Properly notify apache restarts on keystone configuration updates

This uses edit_resource to add a notification in the identity apache
configuration when it gets updated. This is a workaround due to the fact
we are using a version of the apache2 cookbook that is still using
definitions and cannot add notifications with definitions.

This is intended to ensure we only restart apache when the configuration
is updated. Otherwise, the old behaviour was to restart apache on every
run which is problematic in production environments. I have been using
this in our production wrapper cookbook for the past year or so without
any issue.

This will be removed in the Stein release when we migrate to the newer
apache2 cookbook which uses proper resources.

Change-Id: I13de063d1e7ffd356d754eb0f2d8286a3c694836
Signed-off-by: Lance Albertson <lance@osuosl.org>

commit_message:
Properly notify apache restarts on cinder configuration updates

This uses edit_resource to add a notification in the block storage
apache configuration when it gets updated. This is a workaround due to
the fact we are using a version of the apache2 cookbook that is still
using definitions and cannot add notifications with definitions.

This will be removed in the Stein release when we migrate to the newer
apache2 cookbook which uses proper resources.

Change-Id: I7efddef83333ca0794ee3c298ca1a2488defe941
Signed-off-by: Lance Albertson <lance@osuosl.org>

commit_message:
Drop openSUSE 42.3

42.3 will not be maintained anymore and therefore
there is no reason to test it. Users are advised
to upgrade to Leap 15, and we should do the same.

Master and stein test already Leap 15, but we're not backporting new OS
support to old stable branches.

Remove openSUSE 42.3 so that we can remove it from CI.

Change-Id: Ifebd43b02a89d417bf3e3adddfb80e4c7108891b

Make class Vlan support name, If there is no name, use vlan_id.

commit_message:
constraints: bump psycopg2 to 2.8

This bumps the psycopg2 release to the latest one as well
as stops hiding the deprecation warnings because they are
no longer there with the new release.

Change-Id: I33bfa9b71f4bada930dad2ff13d2d708e563d62b

commit_message:
Fix Zun connectivity to itself and Cinder

Zun was misconfigured and defaulted to using public endpoints
which are likely inaccessible from the internal network.
This patch fixes that and removes unused and deprecated
options. Validity of options confirmed from Queens to Train
against respective docs.

Change-Id: I25cc8792351c43eb9ff45465e49fa72ceccd6cb5
Closes-bug: #1840572
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-07 01:03:09.000000000', 'message': 'fix update port bug

when update port set body={"port": {}}, neutron server will return 500.

In function _process_port_binding_attributes(plugins/ml2/plugin.py),
when update port body={"port": {}}
attrs={}
vnic_type = attrs and attrs.get(portbindings.VNIC_TYPE)
vnic_type = {}
because attrs as False, will not execute attrs.get(portbindings.VNIC_TYPE)
vnic_type will be replicated as attrs.

Change-Id: I40d388543387ebdd72f26d761339c1829bef9413
Partial-bug: #1838396
(cherry picked from commit dd080c70b423a56a69abf7e52d1fee0cb7988c92)

commit_message:
fix update port bug

when update port set body={"port": {}}, neutron server will return 500.

In function _process_port_binding_attributes(plugins/ml2/plugin.py),
when update port body={"port": {}}
attrs={}
vnic_type = attrs and attrs.get(portbindings.VNIC_TYPE)
vnic_type = {}
because attrs as False, will not execute attrs.get(portbindings.VNIC_TYPE)
vnic_type will be replicated as attrs.

Change-Id: I40d388543387ebdd72f26d761339c1829bef9413
Partial-bug: #1838396
(cherry picked from commit dd080c70b423a56a69abf7e52d1fee0cb7988c92)

Currently we use writeback caching for disks
on our test vms, however that honors syncs and
IO could become blocked/locked if the sync has

occurs in CI.

Change-Id: Ib09dd7fd41c6b1cbc0e2b707bfc9e4ff8dfa6fad
"}, {'created': '2019-08-16 14:56:57.000000000', 'message': "Move to unsafe caching

Currently we use writeback caching for disks
on our test vms, however that honors syncs and
IO could become blocked/locked if the sync has
not completed with the double virtualization that
occurs in CI.

In theory, we don't need to worry about the
buffer cache behavior for our test VMs.

Overall, it appears that there is a performance
gain of about 10-15% with making this change because
we're not honoring syncs to not lock-up IO.

Change-Id: Ib09dd7fd41c6b1cbc0e2b707bfc9e4ff8dfa6fad
"}]
commit_message:
Move to unsafe caching

Currently we use writeback caching for disks
on our test vms, however that honors syncs and
IO could become blocked/locked if the sync has
not completed with the double virtualization that
occurs in CI.

In theory, we don't need to worry about the
buffer cache behavior for our test VMs.

Overall, it appears that there is a performance
gain of about 10-15% with making this change because
we're not honoring syncs to not lock-up IO.

Change-Id: Ib09dd7fd41c6b1cbc0e2b707bfc9e4ff8dfa6fad

commit_message:
There is no Java 8 in Debian 'buster'

Debian 'buster' release contains Java 11 only. So kafka, logstash, storm
images needed adjustments.

Change-Id: I9f1e809d0ef1955b832dd384912f880088426306
(cherry picked from commit 307ae614546c4d094bae5b49477b0de88b708738)

commit_message:
Ensures monasca-thresh data and worker dirs exist and are empty on start up

This prevents the filesystem from filling up with Apache Storm
temporary files which will otherwise not be cleared.

Change-Id: Ib07e32f4e67e500f10986103d781dfd3874ffdd2
Partial-Bug: #1839149
(cherry picked from commit 16d4cd91d24d48e4cdf90d5c06991b52e00803ba)

monasca-thresh images needed adjustments.

commit_message:
Add advanced image (Ubuntu) to run tests which require it

There are some scenario tests in neutron-tempest-plugin
which require to have image which supports some more
advanced features than CirrOS. For example multicast test
require it.
This commit adds configuration of Ubuntu as such "advanced" image
to be used in scenario jobs.

Change-Id: I878d8179bacd9b66bcc6801c442d5d9a89ae30d7

commit_message:
Add prometheus_client to monasca-agent image

The prometheus_client package is required to use the Prometheus plugin.
It makes sense to include this dependency by default since Kolla Ansible
can deploy many Prometheus exporters, making it easy to scrape their
metrics and store them in Monasca. The increase in size of the container
image is negligible.

Change-Id: I9b0a162513ed436930c4541b758fc9cb2ef97e96
(cherry picked from commit a74aa1bd21b04eceede6cf425a5e56dcacec1412)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-22 07:04:59.000000000', 'message': "Always add NAT rule to a LR when updating a FIP

Before this patch, the NAT rule was attempted to be updated when a
FIP was reassigned to another port. However, this was a noop
since the NAT rule didn't exist anymore causing the reassigning to
be ineffective and to fail silently.

This patch is always adding the NAT rule to the Logical Router
no matter if the Neutron FIP is being added or updated.

The bug that this patch addresses was being hit in the gate with
around a 30% ratio because the maintenance task was fixing it while
tempest was still rying to SSH into it.

Conflicts:
	networking_ovn/common/ovn_client.py

commit_message:
Always add NAT rule to a LR when updating a FIP

Before this patch, the NAT rule was attempted to be updated when a
FIP was reassigned to another port. However, this was a noop
since the NAT rule didn't exist anymore causing the reassigning to
be ineffective and to fail silently.

This patch is always adding the NAT rule to the Logical Router
no matter if the Neutron FIP is being added or updated.

The bug that this patch addresses was being hit in the gate with
around a 30% ratio because the maintenance task was fixing it while
tempest was still rying to SSH into it.

Conflicts:
	networking_ovn/common/ovn_client.py

Change-Id: Icebf4a82f64989112c3ca810b4358de490108c2d
Closes-Bug: #1835029
Closes-Bug: #1833820
Co-Authored-By: Jakub Libosvar <jlibosva@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit d662f444280f5dc0a304a0b4de4767c91304c747)
(cherry picked from commit 13689522d6b97b4d2246e5de6af0447b39ec50ed)
(cherry picked from commit 9490a84f21eef0c112c625227748a61738334d7a)

commit_message:
Permit use of sudo-ldap instead of sudo package

If the sudo-ldap package is providing the sudo command instead of the plain
sudo package, accept that instead of breaking the system and requiring direct
root login intervention to fix things.

Change-Id: I45d7e4617bd59e72b4f0bf2e91750a6830e2a010

subject: Add decryption of credentials
messages: [{'account_id': 30834, 'date': '2019-08-16 17:29:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-08-16 20:47:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\nNeeds a bug (please open one bugs.launchpad.net/keystone ), needs a release note.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-08-16 20:47:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 30834, 'date': '2019-08-20 10:23:40.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-16 17:29:58.000000000', 'message': 'Add decryption of credentials

The method _convert_v3_to_ec2_credential merely converts formats and
expects the credential argument to be decrypted.
However, the backend list_credentials_for_user returns the list of raw encrypted credentials (throung the long chain of methods calls).
The solution is to invoke the _decrypt_credential method of the
corresponding Manager on each element of the list before passing it to _convert_v3_to_ec2_credentials.

Change-Id: I4b263f3dad5fec8c7557f6fc7d0023bbaf4110e2
'}]
commit_message:
Add decryption of credentials

The method _convert_v3_to_ec2_credential merely converts formats and
expects the credential argument to be decrypted.
However, the backend list_credentials_for_user returns the list of raw encrypted credentials (throung the long chain of methods calls).
The solution is to invoke the _decrypt_credential method of the
corresponding Manager on each element of the list before passing it to _convert_v3_to_ec2_credentials.

Change-Id: I4b263f3dad5fec8c7557f6fc7d0023bbaf4110e2

subject: Fix caching behavior
messages:
[{'account_id': 30834, 'date': '2019-08-16 17:02:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-08-16 20:50:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Under no circumstances should there be caching of decrypted elements or re-decryption, it should be a single pass and return. Please show an example of the traceback, please file a bug, and instead of adding in a copy to the decrypt, ensure we never pass through decryption a second time, if we are there is another flaw in our code.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-08-16 20:52:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

also requires a release note.'}, {'account_id': 30834, 'date': '2019-08-20 10:23:16.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-16 17:02:45.000000000', 'message': 'Fix caching behavior

The previous realization of the method led to unstable caching behaviour:
The method modified credential dictionary in-place. For the second and subsequent calls for the same user the caching mechanism
passed the modified in-place dictionary back to the method resulting in a KeyError.
Basically the already decrypted in-place credential was fed back to the _decrypt_credential method by the caching mechanism.
The solution is to modify the copy of the dictionary (as in _encrypt_credential method).
This way the originally retrieved encrypted credential does not get modified
and the caching could properly work.

Change-Id: I8537afad94fae365a4293b6d4ff8e36b911d48d8
'}]
commit_message:
Fix caching behavior

The previous realization of the method led to unstable caching behaviour:
The method modified credential dictionary in-place. For the second and subsequent calls for the same user the caching mechanism
passed the modified in-place dictionary back to the method resulting in a KeyError.
Basically the already decrypted in-place credential was fed back to the _decrypt_credential method by the caching mechanism.
The solution is to modify the copy of the dictionary (as in _encrypt_credential method).
This way the originally retrieved encrypted credential does not get modified
and the caching could properly work.

Change-Id: I8537afad94fae365a4293b6d4ff8e36b911d48d8

commit_message:
Convert tox to native zuul

This change implements a native zuul runner for all role tests.
The change will now run role tests, executing molecule, in the
same was as tripleo-ansible.

To ensure we're passing lint checks, several files have been
updated to resolve lint issues which are now more strict due
to the pre-commit changes.

Scripts have been added to allow developers to run molecule tests
on local environments. These tools will allow developers to mimic
the upstream test process locally.

Change-Id: I07bbcc0b331aa89dafdae5978ea2bb4859a59143
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

commit_message:
fluentd: there is no 'td-agent' for Debian/x86-64

As there is no 'td-agent' package image build fails on 'x86-64'.

We have to wait for TD Agent 4.

Change-Id: I03d38628eee0f0823a58cba3a70df22f29022956

commit_message:
Include iputils package to tempest container

In TripleO side, tempest is consumed from container and it is
built using Red Hat ubi image which does not have iputils
installed and ping operation is common while running scenario
tests.

Adding iputils will install the ping command.

Closes-Bug: #1840645

Change-Id: I5df5329bd7ee1e77556214be7ed264b9c00445e9
Signed-off-by: Chandan kumar <chkumar@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-31 01:56:39.000000000', 'message': 'Fix "unable to delete subnet" in API tests

We have been seeing occasional "unable to delete subnet, One or more ports
have an IP allocation from this subnet." errors in the
neutron-lbaasv2-dsvm-api tests. This tends to happen on slower test hosts.
My suspicion is that since the port deletion is asynchronous, we are trying
to delete the subnet before neutron finishes the port deletion.
The neutron logs [1] appear to back this theory.

This patch adds a wait for the port to finish deletion in neutron before
moving on to delete the subnet.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/68/539068/2/check/neutron-lbaasv2-dsvm-api/ \
    6fba02b/logs/screen-q-svc.txt.gz#_Jan_30_21_33_58_634644

We have been seeing occasional "unable to delete subnet, One or more ports
have an IP allocation from this subnet." errors in the
neutron-lbaasv2-dsvm-api tests. This tends to happen on slower test hosts.
My suspicion is that since the port deletion is asynchronous, we are trying

commit_message:
Fix "unable to delete subnet" in API tests

We have been seeing occasional "unable to delete subnet, One or more ports
have an IP allocation from this subnet." errors in the
neutron-lbaasv2-dsvm-api tests. This tends to happen on slower test hosts.
My suspicion is that since the port deletion is asynchronous, we are trying
to delete the subnet before neutron finishes the port deletion.
The neutron logs [1] appear to back this theory.

This patch adds a wait for the port to finish deletion in neutron before
moving on to delete the subnet.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/68/539068/2/check/neutron-lbaasv2-dsvm-api/ \
    6fba02b/logs/screen-q-svc.txt.gz#_Jan_30_21_33_58_634644

Change-Id: I3baea0319114c9c5a2f8839d4a6b90f9022fefe7

commit_message:
debian: add some images to unbuildable list

We do not have package repositories for opendaylight, telegraf,
xtrabackup images.

bifrost tries to install 'mysql-server' package which is not present in
Debian 'buster'

monasca-grafana has some SSL related issues

Change-Id: I795771569a3dcb9730063bd951c230806a08b3c0

commit_message:
Fix dumping variables when no featureset is defined

In some jobs we don't define featureset, like building images
and containers. In this case we need to set up variables with
option that featureset doesn't exist.
Add checks for featureset defined into common role.
Also add tripleo roles that are used in building containers job
for run condition for these jobs. Add playbooks to be gated as
well.

Change-Id: I24364bda1d47c21259333bc936101e203a1689ca

commit_message:
Use openstack-tempest-all for rpm tempest container

openstack-tempest shipped from RDO does not have the tempest
plugins, It has just tempest cli and library.

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/651601/ updated the rpm package
name while solving different issue and TripleO stein CI,
most of the tempest tests are getting skipped as tempest plugins
are not there.

openstack-tempest-all is the meta package contains all the plugins,
and installing that fixes the issue.

Change-Id: Ifb616b082c9d82f4736e4b688cafc3a58a0c7a9f
Signed-off-by: Chandan kumar <chkumar@redhat.com>

commit_message:
api-ref: add config_drive to 2.75 rebuild response parameters

Change I9d257a003d315b84b937dcef91f3cb41f3e24b53 and the 2.75
microversion returns the config_drive parameter in the rebuild
response and it's in the 2.75 rebuild response sample but was
missing from the response parameters table.

Change-Id: I89eca8638bc0d64b7f320f4ec5c49375bfebdb56

Add Dockerfile to build a py3 swift docker image

This patch contains only a new Dockerfile and few changes to
be able to build both py2 and py3 images.

Next patch should contain changes to add the gate jobs to build
a py3 docker image

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC

commit_message:
Override PATH in subprocess env for apt/dpkg

Whenever we subprocess out from the charm, it is most likely because
we are running tools provided by the payload to mange it.

We should take care to set an appropriate path whenever there is a
chance for external python tools to be directly or indirectly
involved.

Change-Id: Icce4e4a8475b6ad3dc9bf60e59ff2a8ee60d9d1c
Closes-Bug: #1840257

Change-Id: I762a9d406017a9b8677b6b0ffb4dda7b1167dd31

commit_message:
keystone: drop duplicate -DFOREGROUND

No need to specify this as kolla adds this arg automatically
when using kolla_start.

Note that the commit this was cherry picked from does not apply
cleanly, as docker/services/keystone.yaml is used in Rocky and
earlier, while Stein and later use puppet/services/keystone.yaml.

Conflicts:
       puppet/services/keystone.yaml

Change-Id: Ib179e3bbc827cc438519b19e85bda4a9994376b9
Closes-bug: #1832090
(cherry picked from commit 8eaac3026e54a057287301c8c844b54d2c310bc7)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-14 14:51:04.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Make the rabbitmq-ready exec more stringent

Currently we use the following command to determine if rabbit is
up and running *and* ready to service requests:
rabbitmqctl eval "rabbit_mnesia:is_clustered()." | grep -q true

Now we have occasionally observed that rabbitmqctl policies commands
which are executed after said exec['rabbitmq-ready'] will fail.

One potential reason is that is_clustered() can return true *before*
the rabbit app is actually running. In fact we can see it does
return true even though the app is stopped:
()[root@controller-1 /]$ rabbitmqctl stop_app
Stopping rabbit application on node rabbit@controller-1 ...
()[root@controller-1 /]$ rabbitmqctl eval 'rabbit_mnesia:is_clustered().'
true

Let's switch to a combination of commands that check for the cluster to
be up *and* the rabbitmq app to be running:
()[root@controller-1 /]$ rabbitmqctl stop_app
Stopping rabbit application on node rabbit@controller-1 ...
()[root@controller-1 /]$ rabbitmqctl eval 'rabbit_nodes:is_running(node(), rabbit).'
false

Suggested-By: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1835615

Change-Id: I29f779145a39cd16374a91626f7fae1581a18224
'}, {'created': '2019-08-19 06:10:51.000000000', 'message': 'Make the rabbitmq-ready exec more stringent

()[root@controller-1 /]$ rabbitmqctl eval 'rabbit_nodes:is_running(node(), rabbit).'
false

Suggested-By: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1835615

Change-Id: I29f779145a39cd16374a91626f7fae1581a18224
'}, {'created': '2019-08-19 19:56:35.000000000', 'message': 'Make the rabbitmq-ready exec more stringent

commit_message:
Make the rabbitmq-ready exec more stringent

Currently we use the following command to determine if rabbit is
up and running *and* ready to service requests:
rabbitmqctl eval "rabbit_mnesia:is_clustered()." | grep -q true

Now we have occasionally observed that rabbitmqctl policies commands
which are executed after said exec['rabbitmq-ready'] will fail.

One potential reason is that is_clustered() can return true *before*
the rabbit app is actually running. In fact we can see it does
return true even though the app is stopped:
()[root@controller-1 /]$ rabbitmqctl stop_app
Stopping rabbit application on node rabbit@controller-1 ...
()[root@controller-1 /]$ rabbitmqctl eval 'rabbit_mnesia:is_clustered().'
true

Let's switch to a combination of commands that check for the cluster to
be up *and* the rabbitmq app to be running:
()[root@controller-1 /]$ rabbitmqctl stop_app
Stopping rabbit application on node rabbit@controller-1 ...
()[root@controller-1 /]$ rabbitmqctl eval 'rabbit_nodes:is_running(node(), rabbit).'
false

Closes-Bug: #1835615

[{'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-08-19 07:29:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-08-19 07:35:17.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from opensuse423 to goodbye_42.3'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-08-19 11:12:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Looks like this needs the suse vars files updating https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/f507323ec9084bb9bee2a0d91099e8a0/log/job-output.txt#5048'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-08-19 17:18:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-08-19 19:09:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Jonathan, JP, any pointers on which SUSE vars to update here?'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-08-19 20:57:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Jonathan, JP, any pointers on which SUSE vars to update here?

 > Jonathan, JP, any pointers on which SUSE vars to update here?

In here there should be a "suse.yml" which would contain vars specific to suse https://github.com/openstack/ansible-role-qdrouterd/tree/master/vars

The vars file loading is driven by the os/distro name here https://github.com/openstack/ansible-role-qdrouterd/blob/master/tasks/main.yml#L16-L25

We can merge this and make a follow up patch to get the role working / voting on suse, it's fine either way.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-08-20 04:33:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-08-20 04:35:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-08-20 06:55:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I think it's better to switch into two patches, one for removing 42.3 the other one to move to 15. Here we need to change the default jobs and all.

(See also: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1coiPHGqaIKNgCGYsNhEgzswqwp4wedm2XoBCN9WMosY/edit#gid=752070695 )

I will take care of the revert to the initial patch here to just remove and handle the rest in a different patch."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-08-20 06:57:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Published edit on patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-08-20 07:07:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-08-20 07:53:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Fix listing security groups when no rules

When listing security groups in the dashboard and
one or more security groups had no rules it failed
because python throws a KeyError.

This commit changes the neutron API wrapper in horizon
to ensure ensure rule information in SG always exists.

Closes-Bug: #1840465
Co-Authored-By: Tobias Urdin <tobias.urdin@binero.se>
Change-Id: I6e05a7dc6b6655514ee2bff6bd327da86f13900a

All right, I proposed a few patches to sand down some symlink rough-edges, but none of them are blockers:

- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/673121/
- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/673122/
- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/673123/

I also revived my pipeline-ordering patch; this *might* be a blocker; I'm curious about y'all's opinion:

- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/635040/

I'm still debating about the wisdom of writing down symlink_bytes for a hardlink-to-a-symlink. (And it doesn't really help that we only have those bytes for display purposes.) If we drop that, I wonder whether we ought to halt validation at the symlink (which may well be pointing at a name that doesn't exist yet, possibly even *intentionally*).

Also still debating about whether we ought to be tracking bytes in sysmeta vs. just the container override... I guess, better to have it an drop it later than deal with not having it when we realize it was a good idea? It feels like it's just a hack to help us get the size we found in _validate_etag_and_update_sysmeta() out to the override header in handle_put(), though...

I think I like how my _validate_etag_and_update_sysmeta() delta turned out? Minus the extra knowledge of SLO that we need, of course.

I'd be fine with adding the found etag as a header in the 409-on-PUT later.

The strip('"') is a little weird, but could also be addressed later.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-07-29 21:17:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2019-07-31 16:40:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Code-Review-1 Workflow-1

(14 comments)

> All right, I proposed a few patches to sand down some symlink
 > rough-edges, but none of them are blockers:
 > 
 > - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/673121/
 > - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/673122/
 > - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/673123/
 > 

I'm going to have to respin.  I'd like to pull in at least p 673121 since it addresses a defect [1].  Thank you.

 > I also revived my pipeline-ordering patch; this *might* be a
 > blocker; I'm curious about y'all's opinion:
 > 
 > - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/635040/
 > 

I left my comments over there.

 > I'm still debating about the wisdom of writing down symlink_bytes
 > for a hardlink-to-a-symlink. (And it doesn't really help that we
 > only have those bytes for display purposes.) If we drop that, I
 > wonder whether we ought to halt validation at the symlink (which
 > may well be pointing at a name that doesn't exist yet, possibly
 > even *intentionally*).
 > 

Agreed symlinks break the hardlink chain, and their etag/bytes tracking/validation can't realistically extend past them.  I'm going to start working on tests to fully specify the behavior in that scenario.  Thanks for finding that - very helpful.

 > Also still debating about whether we ought to be tracking bytes in
 > sysmeta vs. just the container override... I guess, better to have
 > it an drop it later than deal with not having it when we realize it
 > was a good idea? 

I agree it's better to have it an not need it.

 > It feels like it's just a hack to help us get the
 > size we found in _validate_etag_and_update_sysmeta() out to the
 > override header in handle_put(), though...
 > 

The use of headers (could have been environ keys?) as a data exchange mechanism was a conscious decision to address the (self imposed?) requirement that other middleware's be able to to provide the hardlink information and bypass the validation HEAD request.  But it doesn't hurt my feelings at all to call this approach a hack - all my code is a hack.  If you see a better way - I'm all ears!

 > I think I like how my _validate_etag_and_update_sysmeta() delta
 > turned out? Minus the extra knowledge of SLO that we need, of
 > course.
 > 

I managed to get the diff applied.  I've got some more tests to write, I'll see what they think about it...

 > I'd be fine with adding the found etag as a header in the
 > 409-on-PUT later.
 > 

agreed

 > The strip('"') is a little weird, but could also be addressed
 > later.

Pretty sure it's just cruft - i have it on my list to fix up.  Good eye.

1. If it's a *regression* I think it's only correct to squash, if it's addressing an existing issue it should have a bug report and we should rebase this one on THAT.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2019-07-31 20:38:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2019-07-31 20:47:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 18: Workflow-1

for some reason when I run just the SloSymlink tests I get an error:

	$ nosetests swift/test/functional/test_symlink.py:TestSymlinkSlo
	E.E..E.
	======================================================================
	ERROR: test_hardlink_target_slo_manifest (test.functional.test_symlink.TestSymlinkSlo)
	----------------------------------------------------------------------
	Traceback (most recent call last):
	  File "/home/vagrant/swift/test/functional/test_symlink.py", line 1481, in test_hardlink_target_slo_manifest
	    tf.parsed[0].path.split('/', 2)[2],
	AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'path'

Using self.env.container.conn.storage_path.rsplit('/', 1)[-1] worked better...

I believe the justification for container servers to overwrite the bytes field in listings and throw away the manifest size is because something like "no one cares"

Even though it's obvious to me that having a separate key for "slo_size" w/o information loss would have been better - it's less clear if hardlinks to manifests should track

1) their size
2) the size of the target
3) the size of the thing the target references

We have to track #1 in the bytes field for account stats reporting, #3 was deemed the most-useful piece of information and versioned writes and s3api need to carry the SLO size value forward for listings

I have a diff that drops swift_bytes/content-type handling for SLOs in favor of just writing the symlink_bytes down as the slo-size - I'm going to rebase versioned writes on it and consider the implications'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-08-02 21:18:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-25 01:14:54.000000000', 'message': 'Allow "harder" symlinks

... by embedding some `If-Match: <etag>` semantics in the symlink.

When creating a symlink, users may now specify an optional
X-Symlink-Target-Etag header. If present, the etag of the final object
returned to the client will be checked; if it does not match the
X-Symlink-Target-Etag header, a 412 Precondition Failed error will be
returned to the client. If multiple symlinks are chained together, each
symlink must either use the same X-Symlink-Target-Etag or omit the
header.

Note that, similar to other symlink behavior, no validation is done at
PUT time, only during GET.

Bonus goodness:

- Tighten assertions on Content-Location
- Get rid of source.source-sniffing by making versioned_writes
  symlink-aware ('cause I'm going to want to make it symlink-aware
  later anyway)
- Allow middlewares left of symlink set their own
  Container-Update-Override-Etag when creating a symlink

Change-Id: I179ea6180d31146bb947061c69b1807c59529ac8
'}, {'created': '2019-01-25 21:25:43.000000000', 'message': 'Allow "harder" symlinks

'}, {'created': '2019-03-25 21:34:55.000000000', 'message': 'Allow "harder" symlinks

... by embedding something like `If-Match: <etag>` semantics in the
symlink.

When creating a symlink, users may now specify an optional
X-Symlink-Target-Etag header. If present, the etag of the final object
returned to the client will be checked; if it does not match the
X-Symlink-Target-Etag header, a 409 Conflict error will be returned to
the client. If multiple symlinks are chained together, each symlink must
either use the same X-Symlink-Target-Etag or omit the header.

Note that, unlink "softer" symlink behavior, the target object must
exist with the matching Etag for the "hardlink" to be created.

Since we're validating the Etag anyway, we also force the content-type
to match and send the content-length along to the container listing as
well.

Bonus goodness:

- Tighten assertions on Content-Location
- Get rid of swift.source-sniffing by making versioned_writes
  symlink-aware ('cause I'm going to want to make it symlink-aware
  later anyway)
- Allow middlewares left of symlink to set their own
  Container-Update-Override-Etag when creating a symlink

Change-Id: I179ea6180d31146bb947061c69b1807c59529ac8

exist with the matching Etag for the "hardlink" to be created.

Since we're validating the Etag anyway, we also force the content-type
to match and send the content-length along to the container listing as
well.

Bonus goodness:

- Tighten assertions on Content-Location
- Get rid of swift.source-sniffing by making versioned_writes
  symlink-aware ('cause I'm going to want to make it symlink-aware
  later anyway)
- Allow middlewares left of symlink to set their own
  Container-Update-Override-Etag when creating a symlink

Change-Id: I179ea6180d31146bb947061c69b1807c59529ac8

either use the same X-Symlink-Target-Etag or omit the header.

Note that, unlike "softer" symlink behavior, the target object must
exist with the matching Etag for the "hardlink" to be created.

Since we're validating the Etag anyway, we also force the content-type
to match and send the content-length along to the container listing as

... by embedding something like `If-Match: <etag>` semantics in the
symlink.

When creating a symlink, users may now specify an optional
X-Symlink-Target-Etag header. If present, the etag of the final object
returned to the client will be checked; if it does not match the
X-Symlink-Target-Etag header, a 409 Conflict error will be returned to
the client.

Note that, unlike "dynamic symlink" behavior, the target object must
exist with the matching Etag for the "static symlink" to be created.

Since we're validating the Etag anyway, we also set the content-type of
the symlink to match if the client didn't otherwise specifiy and send
the etag & content-length along to the container listing as well.

Bonus goodness:

- Tighten assertions on Content-Location
- Get rid of swift.source-sniffing by making versioned_writes
  symlink-aware ('cause I'm going to want to make it symlink-aware
  later anyway)
- Allow middlewares left of symlink to set their own
  Container-Update-Override-Etag when creating a symlink
- Set dynamic symlink content type if client doesn't supply something

Co-Authored-By: Clay Gerrard <clay.gerrard@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I179ea6180d31146bb947061c69b1807c59529ac8

commit_message:
Allow "static symlinks"

... by embedding something like `If-Match: <etag>` semantics in the
symlink.

When creating a symlink, users may now specify an optional
X-Symlink-Target-Etag header. If present, the etag of the final object
returned to the client will be checked; if it does not match the
X-Symlink-Target-Etag header, a 409 Conflict error will be returned to
the client.

Note that, unlike "dynamic symlink" behavior, the target object must
exist with the matching Etag for the "static symlink" to be created.

Since we're validating the Etag anyway, we also set the content-type of
the symlink to match if the client didn't otherwise specifiy and send
the etag & content-length along to the container listing as well.

Bonus goodness:

- Tighten assertions on Content-Location
- Get rid of swift.source-sniffing by making versioned_writes
  symlink-aware ('cause I'm going to want to make it symlink-aware
  later anyway)
- Allow middlewares left of symlink to set their own
  Container-Update-Override-Etag when creating a symlink
- Set dynamic symlink content type if client doesn't supply something

Co-Authored-By: Clay Gerrard <clay.gerrard@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I179ea6180d31146bb947061c69b1807c59529ac8

subject: Add retry for DBDeadlock in credential delete
messages:
[{'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-08-15 16:19:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-08-15 17:06:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

in-line comment, but overall looks good. I want to be sure we're not missing other places we need this fix (in the credential backend)"}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-08-15 17:15:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-08-15 21:06:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-08-16 00:48:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-08-16 21:04:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The goal of the release notes is not just end user facing, but it also communicates if a bug has been fixed. It is a trivial addition to a patch set and the feedback is actionable. I am going to maintain a request for a release note on most any bug fix in keystone. In my opinion better to over-communicate that something was a potential issue that has been addressed especially if someone is looking at the release and not looking through the massive history of bugs we have in keystone.

The additional comments were very directed and intended to suss out if this is required for project case as well (mostly). A potential retry is fine if you think (I am asking your opinion as the person fixing the bug) it was warranted, if this is strictly a reactionary bug fix (e.g. a specific issue has occurred in some cases and this is a very targeted fix; this sounds like just that) I'm 100% ok with not adding it for the project case or any other for now. Please keep your eyes open if you see it on the project case (which has very similar code).

For what it is worth, the reason I was asking is because I've been unable to duplicate the bug locally, but I trust this will address your issue and it appears to be very low impact if it causes some limited cases of additional retries.

An additional question for you, what release of openstack are you on? Do you see a need for backporting the fix to your release? Again I've not been able to directly duplicate the issue locally. I am asking with my stable-core maintainer hat on.

Thanks for proposing it and with a release note added I'm happy to push this through."}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-08-19 15:39:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-08-19 15:44:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> An additional question for you, what release of openstack are you on? Do you see a need for backporting the fix to your release? Again I've not been able to directly duplicate the issue locally. I am asking with my stable-core maintainer hat on.

We've seen the issue on scale testing environment of stable/queens TripleO, so yes, we would like to backport this. Heat deletes large number of users when deleting software deployments, however, not so many projects (I can't think of a use-case where projects would be deleted en-mass though)."}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-08-19 16:11:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> > An additional question for you, what release of openstack are you
 > on? Do you see a need for backporting the fix to your release?
 > Again I've not been able to directly duplicate the issue locally. I
 > am asking with my stable-core maintainer hat on.
 > 
 > We've seen the issue on scale testing environment of stable/queens
 > TripleO, so yes, we would like to backport this. Heat deletes large
 > number of users when deleting software deployments, however, not so
 > many projects (I can't think of a use-case where projects would be
 > deleted en-mass though).

That seems reasonable, lets get this landed and then we can backport to active branches. It is a minimal/generally safe change to backport.

Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2019-08-19 16:11:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-08-20 00:15:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-08-20 06:20:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Cherry Picked

This patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/stein as commit 52ef61868930fcccbabe91f27a805211abebde84'}]

commit_message:
Updated from generate-constraints

Held back the following

lxml===4.4.1        nova tests fail https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1838666
websockify===0.9.0  tempest test failing, ping nova
tornado===5.1.1     salt is cauing this, no eta on fix (same as the last year)
stestr===2.5.0      needs merged https://github.com/mtreinish/stestr/pull/265
jsonschema===3.0.2  see https://review.opendev.org/649789
oauthlib===3.1.0    keystone https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/1839393
kubernetes===10.0.1 openshift PINS this, only kuryr-tempest-plugin deps on it
tenacity===5.1.1    failing tests in neutron

Change-Id: I79baeee85f93adb2adfd01b1f02ca511073c8d78

Add retry for sync_point_update_input_data

DBDeadlock. Let's add retry like sync_point_create()

Task: 36299

[{'created': '2019-08-05 12:00:07.000000000', 'message': "Track usage info on RequestWideSearchContext

We were building usage information for each RequestGroup. This
could often involve looking up usage information for duplicated
providers.

Now, track the seen root ids on the RequestWideSearchContext in
a set, and extend a list of usages (on that object) only by those
root ids that we haven't yet seen.

In the process move _get_usages_by_provider_tree to
RequestWideSearchContext and rename it to
extend_usages_by_provider_tree

Manual testing indicates that after the first call to extend... we
can frequently skip it entirely.

commit_message:
Track usage info on RequestWideSearchContext

We were building usage information for each RequestGroup. This
could often involve looking up usage information for duplicated
providers.

Now, track the seen root ids on the RequestWideSearchContext in
a set, and extend a list of usages (on that object) only by those
root ids that we haven't yet seen.

In the process move _get_usages_by_provider_tree to
RequestWideSearchContext and rename it to
extend_usages_by_provider_tree

Manual testing indicates that after the first call to extend... we
can frequently skip it entirely.

Change-Id: I5d05d15d33beb1622a06bde0e32c3f52ba01b448

commit_message:
Revert "Updated from Puppet OpenStack modules constraints"

This is breaking tripleo CI https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1840641
Also pin it in external_modules so it does not get reproposed by bots

This reverts commit 1bc0fe89242cf4620578d07e90afd1fa193a7ec4.

Change-Id: Ieffeafb6b9a1e3f3bbfcb327a8e5ec0ac3b194b1

commit_message:
Add basic minion validation

The minion doesn't actually have any api services so we validate it by
checking the service status on the undercloud. This change adds a role
to validate the heat engine and ironic conductor status on the
undercloud includes additional hosts (undercloud + minion) and there are
no failed services.

Change-Id: I41859f93980dd8cd723ea4ad0f4e6592a78d0082
Related-Blueprint: undercloud-minion

commit_message:
[Queens] Enable container auth support

In queens we didn't use the ansible-role-container-registry so we need
to port the ansible logic that we use into puppet for the docker
service configuration.

Closes-Bug: #1833584
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670082/
Change-Id: I5ee8f8b17ad3424a3bf9d4a420d6c65ab977c6b7

commit_message:
[queens only] Add registry login support

Queens uses puppet to configure docker so we need to add support for
logging into the registry in the puppet class itself.

Change-Id: I8ca84798ba0e89cee9674dbe414de892d5d9e3f1
Related-Bug: #1833584

subject: Ceph-RGW HAProxy config skipped when shouldnt
messages: [{'account_id': 29865, 'date': '2019-08-19 09:14:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 25023, 'date': '2019-08-19 11:15:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 28008, 'date': '2019-08-20 02:41:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-19 09:14:04.000000000', 'message': "Ceph-RGW HAProxy config skipped when shouldnt

Now that group ceph-rgw is in the default inventory (commit c700fdba)
the logic for haproxy_backend_nodes would always select the group
'ceph-rgw' as it will always be defined, regardless of length.

If using the ceph_rgws variable instead of the ceph-rgws group it
meant that the haproxy_backend_nodes equated to an empty group.
So the 'when' criteria in haproxy_service_config.yml did not get met
and the services config was not provisioned.

This fix checks the length of the ceph-rgws group.
If its not greater than zero, haproxy_backend_nodes is defaulted
back to ceph_rgws.

Change-Id: I7ac3e3ba9e64b38ec22704394fcd5f402dd9d7f8
(cherry picked from commit 00417b6856a4dd6363e85df95af67202d95c1529)
"}]
commit_message:
Ceph-RGW HAProxy config skipped when shouldnt

Now that group ceph-rgw is in the default inventory (commit c700fdba)
the logic for haproxy_backend_nodes would always select the group
'ceph-rgw' as it will always be defined, regardless of length.

If using the ceph_rgws variable instead of the ceph-rgws group it
meant that the haproxy_backend_nodes equated to an empty group.
So the 'when' criteria in haproxy_service_config.yml did not get met
and the services config was not provisioned.

This fix checks the length of the ceph-rgws group.
If its not greater than zero, haproxy_backend_nodes is defaulted
back to ceph_rgws.

Change-Id: I7ac3e3ba9e64b38ec22704394fcd5f402dd9d7f8
(cherry picked from commit 00417b6856a4dd6363e85df95af67202d95c1529)

commit_message:
Rename review.openstack.org to review.opendev.org

There are many references to review.openstack.org, and while the
redirect should work, we can also go ahead and fix them.

Change-Id: Ic20bd71e56ba31bb814003d5d9693c61d414cab5

messages:
[{'account_id': 28530, 'date': '2018-07-16 11:48:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-07-16 11:48:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 26222, 'date': '2018-07-16 16:15:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 26588, 'date': '2018-07-23 06:06:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for your good spec.
I think you should read and comply ESTI NFV SOL003[1] and SOL005[2] standard document. See section 10 in SOL003 and section 9 in SOL005.

IMO, introducing a new API "POST /API_ROOT/vnfpkgm/" to tacker is reasonable. 

[1] https://www.etsi.org/deliver/etsi_gs/NFV-SOL/001_099/003/02.04.01_60/gs_NFV-SOL003v020401p.pdf

commit_message:
VNF packages support for VNF onboarding

This specification describes changes needed to be implemented to support
onboarding and instantiation of VNFs described as VNF Package.

Co-authored-By: Hiroyuki Jo <hiroyuki.jo.mt@hco.ntt.co.jp>
Co-authored-By: Tushar Patil <tushar.vitthal.patil@gmail.com>
Blueprint: tosca-csar-mgmt-driver
Change-Id: Icbc6afa192b50b3fe6640207863ada9bac7c1fda

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-15 09:13:32.000000000', 'message': 'Add partition detection to fix osd initialization failure

The changes in the following commit did not completely solve the
problem of osd initialization failure:
https://review.opendev.org/652612

In order to solve this problem, the partprobe command consistent with
ceph-disk is added, and then a loop is added to detect the partition,
which is acquired every 1s. When the partition appears, the osd
initialization is continued.

Change-Id: I0ca255c6358132d9e3acfa6b610b70a78756512c
Closes-bug: #1824787
(cherry picked from commit 342c9f0cd0dc4b97870dc40fab6c5a7d241b40ed)
'}]
commit_message:
Add partition detection to fix osd initialization failure

The changes in the following commit did not completely solve the
problem of osd initialization failure:
https://review.opendev.org/652612

In order to solve this problem, the partprobe command consistent with
ceph-disk is added, and then a loop is added to detect the partition,
which is acquired every 1s. When the partition appears, the osd
initialization is continued.

Change-Id: I0ca255c6358132d9e3acfa6b610b70a78756512c
Closes-bug: #1824787
(cherry picked from commit 342c9f0cd0dc4b97870dc40fab6c5a7d241b40ed)

commit_message:
Fix zun start in devstack IPV6

check the SERVICE_HOST definition in ipv6:
SERVICE_HOST=${SERVICE_HOST:-[$HOST_IPV6]}
this will not the  IPv4 or IPv6 address,
will cause zun start failed check log here [0].

[0]: https://storage.gra1.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/logs_51/677051/2/check/solum-tempest-ipv6-only/564d1fa/controller/logs/devstacklog.txt.gz

Change-Id: I4b40b48ff69d55cee3bfd783d6a4c4862661b160

[{'created': '2018-10-10 05:44:03.000000000', 'message': "Dissuade .gitignore references to personal tools

Developers run all sorts of different tools within Git repositories,
any of which can leave their own special trashfiles all over the
place. We can't every hope to catalog them all, so better to
recommend developers simply configure a global core.excludesfile to
filter the irrelevant files which tend to get created by their
personal choice of tools. Add a comment block explaining this, for
clarity, and remove the one current editor-specific entry present.

We can, and should of course, continue to list files created by the
tools recommended by our workflow (test frameworks, documentation
and packaging builds, et cetera).

This change is a port of Ib58a57267b064e4142686de6c37a70dbff04b9a7
from the openstack-dev/cookiecutter repository.

Change-Id: I9b46f30550f1149c039510dfe17228eb177d8190

commit_message:
Dissuade .gitignore references to personal tools

Developers run all sorts of different tools within Git repositories,
any of which can leave their own special trashfiles all over the
place. We can't every hope to catalog them all, so better to
recommend developers simply configure a global core.excludesfile to
filter the irrelevant files which tend to get created by their
personal choice of tools. Add a comment block explaining this, for
clarity, and remove the one current editor-specific entry present.

We can, and should of course, continue to list files created by the
tools recommended by our workflow (test frameworks, documentation
and packaging builds, et cetera).

This change is a port of Ib58a57267b064e4142686de6c37a70dbff04b9a7
from the openstack-dev/cookiecutter repository.

Change-Id: I9b46f30550f1149c039510dfe17228eb177d8190

The 'update_firmware_sum' is an inband clean step wherein the

ramdisk. The attempt to connect to iLO from IPA ramdisk fails.

commit_message:
iLO firmware update fails with 'update_firmware_sum' clean step

Firmware update using 'update_firmware_sum' clean step fails with
an error stating that unable to connect to iLO address due to
authentication failure.
The 'update_firmware_sum' is an inband clean step wherein the
firmware ISO was inserted from IPA ramdisk. As part of security
fix to ironic the BMC credentials are no more passed to the IPA
ramdisk. The attempt to connect to iLO from IPA ramdisk fails.
The fix has been made to insert the firmware ISO from the
conductor.

Change-Id: I866330c5fc98b1c5bc042c296c3b6e76ed9fd57d
Story: 2006223
Task: 35821
(cherry picked from commit 50bfd9067fdeebcc89117ddab4fdd1573dba565e)

[{'created': '2019-08-19 10:31:49.000000000', 'message': "Pin puppet-rabbitmq

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/677082/ merged today and moved puppet-rabbitmq to 9.1.0
which is breaking our spec tests:

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/e767db93fe214514bebc065a64288548/log/job-output.txt

So we error out with things like:
2019-08-19 07:19:37.527187 | centos-7 | 1) tripleo::certmonger::rabbitmq on redhat-7-x86_64 behaves like tripleo::certmonger::rabbitmq should include the base for using certmonger
2019-08-19 07:19:37.527435 | centos-7 | Failure/Error: include ::rabbitmq::params
2019-08-19 07:19:37.527713 | centos-7 | Puppet::PreformattedError:
2019-08-19 07:19:37.528769 | centos-7 | Evaluation Error: Error while evaluating a Function Call, Could not find class ::rabbitmq::params for centos-7-rax-ord-0010255916 (file: /home/zuul/workspace/spec/fixtures/modules/tripleo/manifests/certmonger/rabbitmq.pp, line: 51, column: 3) on node centos-7-rax-ord-0010255916

But in rdoinfo via I72306636fd7e49169790801f4fe5683bd0fabf0b we did pin
master to a less recent version for exactly this reason 'Pin
puppet-rabbitmq to 2cd0fb2abc001a76e7e35446231773e0e54c1ff8'. (Later in
queens/rocky via Id25cdecef6cdc4ada8563ebf0da0f2e0ee38a8df we pinned
puppet-rabbitmq to the same version)

So let's pin puppet-rabbitmq to a working version for now until someone
does the work to make tripleo compatible with 9.1.0

Change-Id: Ib7c373c10ff7bcd8ec33cb912a8a0a4a32a196e2
Closes-Bug: #1840641

So we error out with things like:
2019-08-19 07:19:37.527187 | centos-7 | 1) tripleo::certmonger::rabbitmq on redhat-7-x86_64 behaves like tripleo::certmonger::rabbitmq should include the base for using certmonger
